dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL BABOWSKY ("BB"), a wiry, dapper-looking man in his mid-thirties, is circling a baby blue Cadillac. A SALESMAN follows on his heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at Salesman)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the beauty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought maybe you saw some chick walking by. I lost my concentration. Why do they call cars 'she'? They never say 'he'... always 'she.' The Salesman shrugs his shoulders.      BB walks around t Cadillac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very nice... very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear YELLING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NORA, a rather plain, but attractive woman in her early 30's, is yelling up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a sick man! Sick! Do ya hear me?! Do ya hear me?!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Peeking around the bannister from the second floor is ERNEST TILLEY, also in his 30's, handsome in a boyish way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do ya think I'm screaming at? How many of you are there up there? There's only you, and you're a sick human being.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, coming down a few steps)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my white on white shirt? The nice one, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like yelling through a wall to you. I'm carrying on about what a disgusting human being you are, and all you want to know is where your white on white shirt is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, the one with the permanent stays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB is now sitting in a cubicle in the office with the Salesman, going over the contract on the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't try to hustle me here ... you know what I mean. I hate being hustled. Give me an honest price, not one of your 'special' deals... give me an honest price. Do I make myself clear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, how much are you willing to pay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There ya go... there ya go... you're doing it... you're doing one of those hustle numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just trying to get an idea how much you're willing to pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four dollars... I want to pay four dollars a month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not an honest answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do ya want to hear? That I'd love to pay three hundred and fifty a month... is that what you want to hear? Tell me how much you want me to pay and I'll tell you how much I'll pay, but don't do a hustle on me... I don't like that. How much do I want to pay? I'd like to pay nothing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley's leaving the house with his tie undone around his white on white shirt. He carries his sports jacket, and Nora is standing at the door yelling at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're being unreasonable.     You don't even want to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what I did... I got no idea. If it's my fault, I'm sorry... I'm sorry. I can do no better than that. A full unconditional apology. Tilley walks down the steps of the house and goes to his car -- a Cadillac. He gets inside, STARTS the ENGINE and pulls away. Nora remains on the porch watching the car ... one lonely figure in a neighborhood of hundreds of duplicate houses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB and the Salesman are coming out of the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you even have the smallest problem, call me personally and I'll just shoot you straight into the service department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I get a loaner if the car's got to stay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we discussed, you get a car if the car has to be kept overnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get a loaner? The Salesman nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drives along, mumbling to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's gonna drive me to my grave... I'm headed to my grave... the woman's driving me insane... it's not supposed to happen this way. He starts moving his head -- stretching his neck from right to left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not even eleven o'clock and my neck is stiffening up. He juts his jaw out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My neck's tight... it's tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB gets into the shiny, baby-blue Cadillac, puts it in reverse and starts to back out of the car lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley is doing neck exercises, rolling his head from left to right as he drives. He sees a red light ahead and starts to slow down, continuing to roll his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB sees the light is red and starts to back into the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley rolls his head back as he slows to 15 miles an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB backs into the street thinking that Tilley's car is going to stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley is still rolling his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley's Cadillac and BB's Cadillac CRASH into one another. The entire right rear of BB's shiny, baby-blue Cadillac is smashed. Both men are shocked and momen- tarily confused. After a beat, both Tilley and BB bolt from their cars. Tilley looks at his buckled hood. BB races up to Tilley's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a lunatic? Can't you see I'm trying to back out of this lot? There's a red light, you shoulda stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? What are you, crazy? You just want to back into the middle of the street like that. A man's just driving along and you back into the middle of the street. What kind of driving is that? What kind of driving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a red light, I'm making a space for myself... that's what I'm doing, in order to get into the street... that's something ya do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came out of nowhere... you bolted out of no place... bolted out of nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bolted! At six miles an hour I'm bolting into the street! You schmuck! You schmuck! He moves toward Tilley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back away from me, do ya hear me? Back away from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back away? You want me to back away? I'll back away. He turns to walk away from Tilley, walks and then turns back and kicks in the headlight of Tilley's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a fucking lunatic! He goes for BB, jumps him and they both fall on to the trunk of BB's car. People have started to gather and immediately jump in and pull BB and Tilley apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a madman! Smashes into me, attacks me... the man is crazy! People continue to pull them apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on now, calm down, calm down. He holds BB's arms. Another MAN grabs for Tilley and tries to pull him off BB.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy... take it easy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to people watching)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get  this guy! Will ya get this guy?   Backs in front of me, and then  kicks my headlight in... and  I'm crazy. You lunatic! Tilley makes another jump for BB.    Again, people try pulling them apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to prison. Death! Death! They're going to give you death! BB looks at his brand new Cadillac with the smashed-in side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Car only has one sixteenth of a mile, and I've been hit. He turns back and looks at Tilley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna get even with you, you son of a bitch... I'm gonna get even with you. This is no ordinary traffic accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to drive a Cadillac, learn how to drive. You want to get even with somebody? You picked the wrong person to get even with. Nobody backs into traffic, smashes my car and says they want to get even. I'm gonna get even!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seated at a booth are three aluminum siding salesmen having their late morning breakfast. SAM PICKLES, a heavyset man in his 50's, delicately butters his toast, and is shaking his head sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did ya see 'Bonanza' last night? Can you tell me why Ben Cartwright had a colored guy stay over?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GIL, who is pouring half a pound of sugar into his coffee looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben Cartwright had a colored guy stay overnight at the Ponderosa? MOUSE, who is picking his teeth with a matchbook, squints at Sam with an investigative look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he know this guy personally?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... he was just passing through, asked if he could stay over, and Ben Cartwright said 'sure thing.' It doesn't make any sense... he invites a strange colored guy in... invited him in to stay. Is that crazy or what? If a colored guy came to my door and said 'can I stay the night,' I'd tell him 'get the fuck out of here'! It's nothing personal, mind you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not a bigot, is that what you're telling us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?   No, I'm not a bigot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're not, how come you're making such a big thing out of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the fact the Ben Cartwright's on the Ponderosa... he's in the middle of nowhere. It's not like he's living on Reisterstown Road with houses all around... we're talking about the West here. It's the idea that a strange guy comes to the door in the middle of the West. It doesn't make sense, that's all I'm saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on... you're a bigot, that's what you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I'll sell tin to anybody ... I don't care who he is. A mark's a mark, whether he's Chinese, Indian or from Mars... I'm thoroughly integrated. Makes no difference to me... I just wouldn't have one of those guys sleep in my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley gets out of his car and enters the diner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts walking to the booth where the other tin men are. On his way he yells over to the waitress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Florence, eggs and the toast, the way I like it. FLORENCE, who doesn't have too much energy, calls back to Tilley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not too gooey.     Coffee right away. She trails the last word. Sam is still talking about his problem with "Bonanza."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just don't believe that 'Bonanza' is an accurate description of the West. I say no more. Tilley slips into the booth next to Sam.    He indicates for Sam to give him more room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, give me a couple of more inches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to take my plate... I'll eat in the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Sam, I'm having a terrible morning. You're not going to believe this, some guy just crashed into me... right in the middle of the street... then he attacks me. One of the loonies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (biting into his toast)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did ya live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I got his name. The police came... God, I can't believe it... the guy's an idiot. He pulls a piece of paper from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, here it is... some Polish name... Babowski... Bill Babowski ... fucking son of a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know the guy... they call him BB.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the son of a bitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he works with Bagel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sells aluminum siding? I don't believe it... of all the people that could run into me, it has to be a fucking tin man. How come I don't know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You musta seen him. He hangs out with Carly Benelli, Cheese ... you know, that group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know the guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you remember, he was up at the Corral one night when we were there... he's a good dancer. You must have seen him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know the guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gil, he doesn't know the guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought he knew him, Sam... I can't believe he doesn't know him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems to be indicating that he doesn't know him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know the guy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a good dancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do, date him? What do I give a shit if he's a good dancer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you saw him. I was amazed, he does a Marengay... I tell you if I was a girl I'd be impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not a girl and you're impressed! Florence comes over and puts down some coffee in front of Tilley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it fresh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's fresh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just asking, Florence.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Florence starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're always just asking. Gil still talking about BB.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, you just can't believe how well this guy does the Marengay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't wait to see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll  tell you one thing,    when I get a  hold of this guy,    I'll break  both his legs and    then he won't  dance the Marengay    too good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see BB pulling up to a building in his banged-up, brand new Cadillac. There are three or four nice Cadillacs parked outside of the run-down building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office is filled with second-hand furniture, mis- matched desks and a conglomeration of styles. In one corner of the room there are two or three GIRLS working the telephones -- canvassing -- talking to people on the phone to see if they're interested in a demonstration on the benefits of aluminum siding. They all speak in a very congenial tone of voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, I represent the Superior Aluminum Siding Company. We will have a representative in your neighborhood today. Would you be interested in seeing the benefits of our aluminum product?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... well, we do aluminum siding which improves the appearance of your house, and improves the insulation... CAMERA MOVES TO ANOTHER GIRL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Which improves the appearance of your house, and improves the insulation... CAMERA MOVES TO GIRL #3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Superior Aluminum Siding Company. We will have a representative... CAMERA MOVES TO another corner of the room where we see 4 "tin men" salesmen sitting around one of the desks playing cards. MOE is beginning to tell a joke. He is a man in his 50's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the guy goes to the doctor for a physical... they do all those tests, all that stuff, blah, blah, blah... BB enters the scene and goes over and gets himself a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...   Doctor says 'when we get all the   information back, we'll give you   a call.' Leaves the doctor. One   day the telephone rings... the   guy goes and picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (immediately aggravated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, the guy picks    it up. He gets a phone call... it's    the doctor on the line. Doctor     says 'I've got some bad news and    some worse news.' BB join the tin men to listen to Moe's joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy    says 'Well, let me hear the bad    news first.' 'The bad news is,    you've got twenty-four hours to    live.' The guy says 'What's the    worse news?' Doctor says 'I    forgot to call you yesterday.' They all laugh. LOONEY, a thin guy who twitches and blinks a lot, stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good... I like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never heard bad news and worse news... smart joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... I like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dumb, but good. BB, who is not laughing, stands behind Cheese who throws 50 cents into the card game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up it fifty cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I call... I call. I'm in on this one... I call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We get it, you're calling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carly, get out of the hand... I'm holding serious cards. Very serious cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's bluffing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'm lying, I'm dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ballsy move. Moe throws his hand in, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to BB)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get the new Cadillac?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.    It's already been hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't have it     five minutes, backing out of     the place, and a guy comes out     of nowhere and bangs into my     car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what ya got? Cheese throws his hand down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pair of sixes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacks.     Win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!    Pair of sixes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (about car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much damage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet it's six hundred bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six hundred bucks? I'd get rid of the car. That much damage it won't be any good. You may have dented the frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't dent the frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you hit the frame, the car doesn't ride right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't hit the frame! I'll tell you this, I'm gonna get the son of a bitch. If he would have apologized or something, but this guy gets out, tries to push me around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... the guy's totally off the wall. He takes a sip of his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna get him... just for the fun of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB's Cadillac moves through the neighborhood, and we see homes that all look to be about 30 to 40 years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moe is with BB in the Cadillac.   BB is driving.   Moe is looking through some papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, let me see... we gotta be at the Hickey house at four. (he looks at his watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about three-twenty now... we've got some time on our hands. You want to get some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm up to here with the coffee. He indicates his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got any good pool halls around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what would be fun to do..? Let's try the Life Magazine routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slightly run-down.   We're looking THROUGH the LENS of a 35mm camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I think we've got to come over about two feet. The SCREEN SHAKES as BB moves the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HOUSEWIFE is looking through the curtains, suspiciously CAMERA MOVES TOWARDS the window and we see Moe and BB moving the 35mm camera around on a tripod. We can faintly hear their talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think this  is a better position... the light is  hitting it, which is accentuating  the effect we're going for.   It's very good... very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a creative pose)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This shows the flaws in the structure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB and Moe at the camera and tripod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath, to Moe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a loud voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is going to be terrific in Life Magazine. (even louder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific in Life Magazine! (under his breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on outside, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in loud voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This should be our single biggest issue of Life Magazine. We see the Housewife coming out of her front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingo! The Housewife approaches BB and Moe suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.   What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I hope we're not disturbing you, ma'am. We're with Life Magazine... we'll be out of here in just a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still looking through camera; to Moe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move the tripod another foot... another foot. Moe moves the tripod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, Life Magazine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up from camera)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two minutes, ma'am, and we'll be out of here. We just need the picture for Life Magazine, and we'll be out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life Magazine?     I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very simple. Ya know, we're doing this layout about the benefits of aluminum siding -- a 'before' and 'after' kind of presentation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 'before' picture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they see your house, and another one done with aluminum siding... the other house looking so much more beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Life Magazine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a special issue on home improvements and ways to beautify your home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wonderful issue... it's one of the finest pictorial things we've done here at Life... the ways you can improve your house. (he adjusts the camera)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna be out of here in no time, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gonna look very good, BB.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My house is going to be the 'before'? Can't mine be like the 'after'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no... we've got a house that looked like yours and it's been done in aluminum... it's very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... really shows the contrast of what a house can look like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it cost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? The aluminum siding? Oh... I don't know the figures offhand. Do you have any idea, Moe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's fairly reasonable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could my house be the 'after' in Life Magazine and you get another house for the 'before.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean have your house as the 'after' and find another house that looks like your house for the 'before'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it possible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do ya think, Moe?     Would that be ethical?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we didn't sign any agreement with the 'after' house. We'd have to move very quickly, ma'am... you know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd have to work out an arrangement with an aluminum siding company and they'd have to do the job very quickly for us to make our deadline... we've got a deadline, that's the problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How quickly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB, what do you think? Can we slide the deadline, or what? Six or seven days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pressing it. Do you think we could manage it, Moe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pushing it, BB. (to Housewife)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time would your husband be home, 'cos he'd have to go over the figures with the salesman... that's if there's a salesman available this evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be home at seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We might be able to work it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB and Moe are sitting on a sofa sipping coffee, looking as if they were members of the family. The Housewife and her HUSBAND are sitting across the dining room table from Carly. Carly is going  through papers, adding up figures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... we've got a total of thirty-seven hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-seven hundred dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, we're gonna be in Life Magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Moe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moe, did you call  the office and make sure we  can hold up the issue until this  job is completed? This house really  could be a showcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-seven hundred dollars!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you what... I've got an idea. Do you mind my guys working on a Saturday? 'Cos if my crew can work on Saturday next, that'll free my guys up on Monday. Yeah, that'll really help me out on another job. Anyway, if we can do that, I think I'll be able to knock off three hundred and fifty dollars from the job. You see, I've got an overlapping situation on Monday... I don't want to go into it. What do ya think? We got a deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are the benefits of aluminum siding? One: you never have to paint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You have much greater insulation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It cuts down on your heating bills...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what we've got is efficiency and the beautification of your home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley is packing up his sample case. A middle-aged HUSBAND and wife sit on a couch across from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm sorry, Mr. Tilley, I just can't afford it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't even got to discussing terms. There are so many friendly financial arrangements that would hardly be a bite into your weekly salary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... not this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, as I said, you can always reach me... you've got my card, and when the time comes, let's talk. The Husband and wife stand to show Tilley to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, give my best to your little son... wonderful kid there. What's his name again, Ronnie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy, right.    Well, good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam is singing to the RADIO. Tilley opens the back door and throws his sample case inside. He gets in the driver's seat and slams the car door angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I had 'em... I was this close. He demonstrates with his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The amount of time you spent there, I thought you were ready to send for me to close it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn!    I thought I had 'em. Tilley STARTS the CAR and pulls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a piano bar with an intimate restaurant at one end. The PIANIST is playing "The Girl From Ipanema."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Tall and tan and young and lovely, the girl from Ipanema goes walking, and when she passes each one she passes goes... "Ah!"' The last word of the verse -- "Ah" -- has great emphasis put on it and is lengthened considerably. The people sitting around the piano all join the pianist and say "Ah" in unison. CAMERA MOVES OVER TO a table where Mouse, Sam, Tilley, Gil and a few other tin men set. WING, the head of Gibraltar Aluminum, a tall, strong, imposing figure, holds court. The table is filled with papers, folders, etc., as if Wing's office desk had been trans- ported to the bar. He's reviewing a paper from a job that Mouse has done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-six hundred dollars. This looks like a sound deal. They own their own house... we won't have any problem getting the financing for them. Real good, Mouse. He picks up his check book ledger and writes out a check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (writing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, that's one thousand, one hundred and thirty-eight dollars. Finishes writing check and hands it to Mouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, boss. Pleasure doing business with ya. Mouse takes the check and pockets it.   Wing turns to Tilley and Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, what's your guys' story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing again... came up short. Let me get a little advance... three hundred, just to carry me for a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley, I'm already carrying you for, what is it -- twenty-three hundred? Something like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem... just in a little slump here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't try to go walking on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, walking? You think I'm gonna work somewhere else... you've been very good to me... very honorable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's always said that about you, Wing. Always said that about you... he has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you hundred and fifty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wing, I need a bit more than that... I got expenses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with your wife?   She doesn't work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but how much is she gonna make working at the Social Security office? Wing writes out a check and gives it to Tilley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Wing, can't you do better than this... a man in my position in terms of this firm... I dunno...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'll give you two hundred. Wing changes amount of check and hands it to Tilley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling to cocktail waitress)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, can you get me some Marlboros and a 7 and 7?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And some scotch, straight up. Tilley pockets the check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now listen, guys, we got a problem here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mouse)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she hear me say scotch straight up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sources tell me this Home Improvement Commission is for real... it's no jackpot. These guys are going to be a real pain in the ass, so any of the scams that you guys are pulling, they get wind of it, they take your license and it's goodbye to this business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They take away your license? They take away your livelihood? What kind of people are these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have no respect for the working man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which scams are they talking about? They got a list?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any irregularities, you know, selling a house on the pretense that it's a model house and every job sold in the area they get a kickback... the Life Magazine hustle... you guys know all the bullshit numbers we can run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus! What a pain in the ass. Do you think this commission's gonna stick around or is it gone with the wind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They take your license?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB's Cadillac moves along the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB and Moe are in the car driving along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't mind seeing Africa some time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not me. I don't want to go where they've got snakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've got snakes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard they've got snakes that'll outrun a horse through the grass. They got a snake that bites you... you got eleven seconds to live. No thank you. I don't want to spend my good money to visit with that kind of jeopardy. I'd like to go to a place where... hold it! He hits the brakes suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong? BB backs his car halfway up the street. He stops in the driveway of the Pimlico Hotel parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy who ran into me... that's his car. He puts the car into park and opens the car door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back, Moe.    I'm gonna even the score. He gets out of the car, quickly walks over to Tilley's Cadillac, and with a swift kick, he kicks the headlight that isn't already broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley, Sam, Mouse and Gil are about to leave the hotel. They're putting their coats on just inside the closed door. Tilley is halfway into his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mouse)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me eight points I take the Knicks over the Lakers for 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too big a spread. We hear the    sound of BREAKING GLASS. Tilley responds t the sound.     He looks out of the glass doors and sees B kicking in    the headlight of his car. BB runs back towards his    car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that fucking lunatic again. He races out of the door of the hotel towards BB's car which pulls away and speeds down the street. Several of the tin men run after Tilley. He stands in the street watching the car disappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still looking after the car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you believe this guy?    Is he sane or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he got, a gnat up his ass? What the hell's wrong with the guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you recognize him from the Corral?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know the guy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll never forget his Marengay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you something, if Mr. Marengay wants to play... we'll play.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: of the porches of one row house on top of another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley is letting himself into his house. He goes into the kitchen where Nora is sitting, drinking a cup of coffee and working on a crossword puzzle. He takes off his coat and throws it on a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up from the crossword puzzle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at you, quarter to three and home already. What happened? You and the fellas run out of things to talk about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please! I'm out there working myself to the bone, trying to make a living. He goes over to the refrigerator and gets himself some orange juice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a five letter word for a Portuguese overseas province?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try Macao.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M-A-C-A-O... that fits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you doing up so late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're off tomorrow. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think this place may be a little too large for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about... this match box?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's got a lot of overhead to it. What do you do... spend your time in the bedroom and the kitchen, that's all. So why do you need a living room and a dining room. He walks over to the back door and looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do ya need a back yard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not selling anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in a slump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last year I'm number three top seller... year before, right up there. I  can't get my momentum going this year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you will. You always do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I like the idea of all this overhead breathing down my neck. When you have a place like this, that's a lot of overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? The monthly payments on your Cadillac are more than this whole house. Why don't you get yourself something cheaper, like a Chevy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't instill confidence in my clients. Cadillac means that you're dealing with someone of importance. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I had a couple tonight... they just slipped away... slipped away. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna take a bath -- my neck's been tight since this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll turn out the lights. Nora gets up and puts the cups in the sink -- gives a big sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley is in the tub, lathering himself.   Nora enters and sits on the side of the tub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Tilley, we hardly ever do things together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do things together that are enjoyable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would we do together for it to be enjoyable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we went on a picnic... it would be fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand a picnic... we just go some place... we put a thing on the ground, and we eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... it's nice to do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? I don't get it. It's better sitting at home and watching TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think there's something nice about a picnic... it's fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's fun about it? Ants get into the food... there's bees. I don't get it. We have to drive, it takes maybe an hour to get there, then you sit in grass and eat. Why is that fun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just thought it might be nice to do something together, that's all... thought it might be fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't sound like fun to me... you take the stuff you've got here in the house, you take it someplace to eat it. It's just as much fun eating in front of the TV, and we do that together, don't we? No ants and no bees... much more comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scrub my back, will ya, Nora. Nora picks up the back brush, puts soap on it and starts scrubbing Tilley's back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not too hard! (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get me wrong, I'm willing to do anything with you. I'm just a little stymied by a picnic. If you want to go, send me a postcard. Nora drops the brush in the tub and walks out of the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Tilley's Cadillac cruising the streets, obviously looking for someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley is driving with Gil in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you make a left here. Tilley turns the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... there it is... that's the place... Superior Aluminum... that's it over there. As Tilley pulls up we see BB's car parked outside of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Mr. Marengay... here I come. He reaches into the backseat of the car and takes out a crowbar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Tilley, don't go too wild...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll show the son of a bitch. He gets out of the car, crosses to BB's Cadillac, and smashes in the windshield and all of the windows of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he smashes, wildly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll get a lot of air... won't be too stuffy in this car when I'm finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling from Tilley's Cadillac)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick, Tilley... let's get out of here. Tilley runs back to his car and drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of a map of a 15 block area of Baltimore. Colored pins are in place indicating various homes that have been provided with aluminum siding. Another pin goes into place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a good sale, Double B. Just got a call on a loan... we're in business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see BAGEL. He's a little guy with a black Fedora and baggy pants held up with suspenders. BB stands with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This whole section has been very fertile for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moe, Looney and Carly are talking to STANLEY FRANKS, a young guy in his early 20's. He is dressed in the "Ivy League" look of the times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Stanley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you wanna get into the tin game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money's good, I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lot of crazy people you're gonna run into when you're knocking on those doors. Hermits that don't see the outside world, Jehovah's Witnesses that try and sell you the Bible at the same time you're trying to sell them tin. People that are just lonely and want to have conversations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time you step in that door, you've got to be fast on your feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quizzing Stanley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the best way to qualify a mark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know if you can get the upper hand? How do you know if you're dealing with a guy who's in an inferior position to you, or superior position? How do you know? Moe puts Stanley on the defensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just have to talk and feel your way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick way... get a book of matches out of your pocket to light your cigarette... you drop the matches on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy bends down to pick up the matches for you, you got a mark... you got this guy in your pocket. If he looks to you to pick it up, you've got a long, hard, tough sell on your hands. BB walks over to the guys, having just poured himself some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to get in good with these people... you want to win their confidence? Good thing to try... get a five dollar bill, take it out when the guy's not looking, drop it on the ground. Guy looks back, pick it up, hand it to him and say, 'Mr. Blah blah, you musta dropped this five dollar bill on the ground.' Two things happen... he says, 'It's not mine,' you say, 'Musta been, 'cos it's certainly not mine,' or the guy takes it. Right away this guy is thinking you must be one hell of a nice guy... you're in. You start chipping away... you start getting inside those people. Stanley is quite taken by their information.   BB puts his cup down and grabs his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Moe, let's split.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Stanley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we'd better go, too. Come on, Stanley. (to Carly who is hanging behind)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me and Stanley. It's like a first date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB and Moe approach BB's Cadillac. He sees that all the windows have been smashed in. Moe looks to BB. Looney walks up from behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You got a special bargain when you bought this car? They come cheaper without windows? BB reaches into the car and picks up a handful of broken glass. He tosses it up and down in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy's looking to play tit for tat. That's not my game. I'm gonna play hardball. BB throws the glass down on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Looney, quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on? Looney just nods for them to go, and they start to walk over to Looney's Cadillac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna find    out everything about this son    of a bitch, and then I'm gonna    find the one thing that cuts him    to the quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go inside... make some calls. BB nods and they start back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of a pool ball ricocheting off an eight ball. The eight ball drops into the pocket. Tilley throws down his pool stick. We  see his partner is Mouse. Gil sits in a chair against a wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it! Damn it! I can't believe it... I can't believe I did that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then, believe it. There's no sense not to believe it, because you did it... so believe it. That's twenty more... you owe me sixty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I can't add? He goes to rack to re-set. Mouse     goes over and puts a nickel in the juke box. A RECORD     slips into position, and Harry Belafonte's "Banana Boat    Song" begins. Mouse in unison with the record, sings,    and is totally caugh up in the song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Dayo!... da, da, da, da, day. Daylight come and he wanna go home...' He sings very loudly, especially on the chorus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (facetiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, this is going to be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Dayo!... da, da, da, da, da, da, da.' (he hits his pool cue on the ground for emphasis)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Daylight come and he wanna go home...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam is going through some papers on a desk, and comes across an IRS letter addressed to Tilley. He notices that it hasn't been opened. He looks at the postdate mark -- it's five weeks old, dated January 3, 1963.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! We can hear the "BANANA BOAT SONG" through the door, with MOUSE SCREECHING along with it. Sam takes the letter and goes through the door to the pool hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He approaches Tilley who's just finished racking the balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley. He nods for Tilley to go over to him. They start to walk together through the darkened areas of the Pool Hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Found this on your desk while I was going over some papers. He hands the letter to Tilley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the IRS. I never even remember seeing it. I must have left it with my other bills. I wonder what it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's a refund check. Tilley opens the envelope and looks at the document.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hum... says here that they haven't received my 1962 taxes. They seem to be saying that they didn't get my check for four thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? It must be a clerical error.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe they spend all that time and energy to write to me... to single me out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?   You didn't pay your taxes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I probably forgot... people forget their taxes all the time... just slipped my mind... I got so many things on my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured they could wait a few years... it's not like they need my money to build a bomber. You think they're waiting for my money before they dig a new road? Are they all sitting there saying, 'Well, it's time we went to see that guy on Pimlico Road... can't run this government without his four thousand dollars.' (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured they'd give me a little leeway. I'm going to pay them... I know I've got a debt... I just need a little leeway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't mess around with the government. Why don't you go to H & R Block, they'll take care of your taxes for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm gonna let some schmuck know all my business... have some guy pull me over the coals for spending on this and that. I need some privacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taxes is serious stuff, Tilley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can just see that schmuck in that little tax shop telling people my business... how much I make... how much I spend... no way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I can say, is you better get a lawyer or somebody to look into this, 'cos the IRS, they don't fuck around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just what I need in my life right now... I'm in a slump and I've got the IRS on me. Like when something goes wrong, it's like... He throws his arms up in the air in exasperation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Nora leaving her house,  walking down the    steps and getting into her car. She   STARTS the ENGINE    and pulls away.  CAMERA HOLDS for  a moment, and then    INTO FRAME comes Moe's car with BB  sitting shotgun.     They follow Nora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora enters. Ten seconds later, BB enters. He pulls a shopping cart from the stall, and follows Nora.

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: as he walks up to the front of the supermarket and looks through the window.

dialogues.speaker: FROZEN FOOD SECTION
dialogues.text: Nora is stopped with her cart and is deciding on vege- tables. BB has a pile of frozen dinners in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Nora)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are these any good do ya know? These TV dinners?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think they're too good for you, not a lot of 'em anyway. She continues to choose her frozen foods.     BB continue talking to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm over it now, but it was a very trying time... very trying... I've only just started eating again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what would be a lot more healthy and satisfying is to get yourself a chicken... just pop it in the oven for a couple of hours with a little bit of seasoning on it. Makes a good meal, and you can make sandwiches with the leftovers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then you have to sit and watch it cook. Something seems sad about a man sitting alone in a house and watching a chicken cook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moe is looking through the window of the supermarket. From his POV we see BB and Nora. BB says something and Nora laughs. Then Nora says something and BB laughs, holding her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's an amazing sort... he's got the gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man sits behind the wheel of a plain-looking Ford. Stanley, the new tin man, pulls up in his car behind him, gets out and walks to the other man's car. He kneels down and talks to the driver of the car. There seems to be a serious exchange but with the sound of TRAFFIC and the cars passing THROUGH FRAME, we're un- able to hear what is taking place. Stanley nods, taps the side of the car, car drives off. Stanley goes back to his car and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley is selling to a MAN and his WIFE. The Man wears a seersucker suit and a bow tie -- he is a mousie little man, and his Wife is the female equivalent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Tilley. I can't believe it... this is the most generous thing anyone's ever done ... Swell! Like a gift from heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lord has certainly blessed us this evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what can I say... I'm a modest person... I just do what I can to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks again. He opens the door for Tilley and Tilley walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the door closes behind Tilley, he goes to where Sam's car is parked and gets in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what's the scoop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got 'em! He's very excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a look at this, Sam. Tilley shows him the written contract. Written across the front of the contract in big, bold, black letters are the words: "THIS JOB IS FREE." Sam looks at Tilley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you fucking crazy? You just gave them forty-two hundred dollars in aluminum siding free?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the best scam I've ever thought of in my whole life. He kisses his hands with wild smacking sounds.     He's ecstatic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in my blood... I'm brilliant ... I'm fucking brilliant... this is such a brilliant scam... I'm beside myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here it is... you go back in the house and this is what you say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Tilley is crazy... he had a nervous breakdown. WIDEN to include Man and Wife from before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been under a lot of pressure recently... he snapped... he had a nervous breakdown... it's the saddest thing I've ever seen. Let's be honest about it, nobody gives away forty-two hundred dollars' worth of aluminum siding free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it was very generous, but sometimes the Lord moves in mysterious ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you something, when I go and see his boss and show him this contract, he's out of this business... he'll lose his home ... his wife and kids will be thrown out onto the street. He'll probably spend some time in an institution, so God knows what will happen to his wife and kids. Anyway, it's not your problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do they have to be thrown out onto the street?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't expect his boss to pick up the forty-two hundred job, do ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's a bad state of affairs. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me ask you something, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think there's some way you could work with me to try and resolve this, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's look at it this way, what if I can sell you this job at a wholesale price... kind of lessens the burden. The big boss won't get so angry, and maybe won't throw the guy's wife and kids out... at least they'll have a roof over their heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of wholesale price are we talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a cup of coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get you a coffee... won't be a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just sit down and kick this around. The Wife goes into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling to Wife)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No hurry, ma'am. The Man turns to sit down, and as he does so, Sam throws a $5 bill on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you doing throwing your money around? He bends to pick up the $5 note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found a five-dollar bill, here by the side of the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is crowded... jumping with activity. A local band is playing on a tiny stage. BB's on the floor dancing with a girl. He's doing some good moves, and it's obvious that he's a real crowd pleaser. Sitting at the bar are Looney, Stanley and Carly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The buzzard had a great gimmick. You know, when it came time to measure a job, he'd cut the yardstick and reglue it together ... he took out seven inches so his square footage would always be higher. That way he'd always make a few extra bucks on the job.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Stanley laughs and looks at Carly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... he'd always put his hand over the break when he was measuring. Nobody looks at a yardstick to see how long it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never did that... I never did that... I was never very good in arts and crafts. I  could never make the ruler come out right. The song ends.

dialogues.speaker: BB
dialogues.text: He pats his dancing partner on her rear, she walks back to her table, and BB walks over to where Moe is sitting. BB picks up his beer can, holds it up to Moe as if he's going to make a toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's to Nora. Moe smiles, picks up his can, they tap their cans, and both take a swig of their beers.

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: Stanley is really enjoying the stories Carly and Looney are telling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else? Give me another story ... these stories are great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute... I've got one. You know it's like the faster you can start spiking a job, the guy can't back out of the deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoe had some customers that he thought was fragile on coming for the buy. He'd say to the guy 'here let me show you how bad a shape your house is in,' and he'd rip off a piece of wood, maybe fifteen feet wide. The guy's house looks like shit so it makes it hard for him to back out of the deal when half the side of his house is missing. The Shoe's a fucking wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam is driving and Tilley is rubbing his hands together with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fantastic, Sam! A twenty-seven hundred sale! 'This job is free'! What a beaut! I'm out of the slump! Tilley's riding high again ... Tilley's back! We ought to go and celebrate. Let's go to the Corral and have a drink... we can turn the paperwork in a little later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gil says that's where 'Marengay' hangs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gil keeps saying it... I've never seen him. (laughing and hit- ting the dashboard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm riding high... twenty-seven hundred dollars... 'this job is free'... the man went insane... lost control of himself... his wife and children are out on the street! (he laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I'm brilliant... I'm fucking brilliant... I can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: MOE AND BB
dialogues.text: They're looking at the girls, sizing them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to a girl)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See that one, if you were married to that one two weeks you'd have to put your head out of the window for air... this one smothers. (looking over to another girl)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That one is the kind that can't live without you... (whiney voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... 'Where were you? When will you be home?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should get out of here. I told my wife I'd be home early tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ!    It's not even one o'clock yet. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long you been married now? What is it? Twelve... twelve years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy God! Sixteen years? What do you think? Is it worth it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to answer. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems better than if she wasn't there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite a recommendation... can't wait to do it. He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: Tilley and Sam come through the door and walk over to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotch straight up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to barman)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotch straight up and a rum and Coke for me. He looks around the room at the women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like there's good action here tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you expect, it's half price night for divorced women. The place is hopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look how much more complicated things are now. There used to be a time you met a girl, you courted and then you got married and lived happily ever after. Now, see that one over there... (he points to girl at a table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... that's Helen Armstrong... maiden name used to be Tudor. Get this, she dated Charlie Rider when I was in high school, seemed like they were together forever. They broke up, she started to go with Lenny Mardigian, they got married, she's Helen Mardigian. That goes on two years... three years, something like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They divorce, dates Billy Small for a couple of years, lives with John Isaacs for a year, marries Tommy Selnini... that marriage goes in the toilet, but fast. Now she's dating Charlie Rider who was divorced by Evelyn Chartoff who used to be Evelyn Gage before that. (beat; he looks at Moe and laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So much for relationships.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm beginning to believe in God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were never one of those atheists, were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not saying that, but I'm beginning to give God more thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what did you do? Have some kind of religious experience?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell ya... I took my wife for lunch yesterday... we went and had some smorgasbord, and it kind of happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You found God at the smorgasbord?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, people have religious experiences like on a lake or when they go up into the mountains, that kind of thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe... but I had mine in a smorgasbord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, you're too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to get myself a salad and I started to see all these vegetables, you know how they have all those salads laid out so that when it's time to get to the main course you won't eat too much... that scam to get you filled up so you don't eat too much chicken and beef and all that other stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah... I get the point. So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I see celery, I see the lettuce, tomatoes, cauliflower... and I think, all these things come out of the ground... they just grow out of the ground. They had corn -- out of the ground... radish -- out of the ground. You say to yourself, how can all these things come out of the ground? You know what I'm talking about? All these things are out of the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not understanding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, how can that be? It just happened that way? And I'm not even getting into the fruits... I'm just dealing with vegetables right now. With all those things coming out of the earth, there must be a God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not getting the same religious effect that came over you. I don't know why, but I don't feel like running to a church to pray right this second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta admit, it's amazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah... (he turns away and looks across the room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it. See the guy over there? He looks in the direction of BB.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the son of a bitch who crsahed into my car. Sam looks over to BB.

dialogues.speaker: BB AND MOE
dialogues.text: BB's looking through the crowd and sees Tilley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it!    Mr. Banana Head is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That crazy guy that banged into my car and smashed my windows in. I don't fucking believe it! I'm gonna get him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna get him! Both BB and Tilley weave their way through the crowd to get to one another. In the confusion of all the people, they both go right past one another and then look around for one another. They see that they're in the opposite direction, and end up going towards one another again. Moe and Sam wander over to their guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a lot of nerve banging into my car, and you've got a lot of fucking nerve smashing my windows in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you talking about?     Why would I want to break your windows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't smash my windows in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a hard-working guy... I don't go around breaking windows. I've got better things to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't break my windows?! You didn't break my windows?! He pushes Tilley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Push me one more time and I'm gonna have to redefine your face. BB pushes him.     Tilley starts to go for BB and they scuffle about.     Moe and Sam try to pull the guys apart

dialogues.speaker: LOONEY AND CARLY
dialogues.text: They move through the crowd to BB and Moe. The band keeps playing. Moe and Sam, with the help of Looney and Carly, pull Tilley and BB apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, let's go outside... let's settle this in the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no! You're not gonna get near my car... you're not gonna kick in my headlights again... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... What am I talking about? I didn't even drive tonight. You wanna duke it? Let's go. They both head out the door. The other tin men follow, and others who have been paying attention to this alter- cation, also follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley and BB   come out of the club and start to look fo a place in the   lot where there's some room to fight. Th crowd eagerly   follows right on the heels of BB and Till BB and Tilley   both take off their sports jackets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing the people gathering around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this? What is this crowd here? We're charging admission?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back away... give me some elbow room. BB and Tilley both take up  fighting stances and circle one another looking to take  a shot. A police car pulls into the lot. The sound of   the tires on the gravel catches Moe's attention and  he sees it's the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly to BB and Tilley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police! Tilley and BB immediately drop their guards and lean against a car. One cop gets out of the police car and heads into the club, the other cop stays behind in the car. No one knows quite what to do since the policeman is so nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually leaning against the car; to BB)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a lucky man... the police showed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see who's the lucky one. He picks up his coat and leaves with Moe.

dialogues.speaker: LARGE CA
dialogues.text: with lit candles on it.    The cake reads "FAREWELL ADA."

dialogues.speaker: CAKE
dialogues.text: as it passes row upon row of SECRETARIES typing in the Social Security office.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: All of a sudden everything goes black, the typewriters stop and all we can see are the lit candles. We hear a huge chorus from all of the Secretaries in the Social Security office:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surprise!!! Lights go on again, and we see a group of GIRLS gathered around the cake placed on one of the desks. At the center of the group is ADA, in her late twenties, and very pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never expected this.   What a lovely cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blow out the candles then. Ada blows out the candles, missing a couple, and getting help from one of the other Girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine candles for nine months! Everyone laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll miss you, Ada... you'd better bring that baby in to visit us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Register him for his social security number. A couple of girls hand around glasses of Coca-Cola. Nora stands in the midst of the girls, pleased for Ada. She yells out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love ya, Ada, and if you're smart you won't come back. The cake is being passed out, and people are talking -- it has become somewhat of a party atmosphere. Nora turns to her friend, NELLIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just decided... I'm going out with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to. I just want to know what it's like to be with someone else. She sips her Coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because if what I've got with Tilley is as good as it gets, I just... (she shrugs her shoulders)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I gotta know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how are you going to manage it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley doesn't get home until at least two in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you know what you're doing ... you speak to some guy at the frozen food section for five minutes, you could jeopardize your whole marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything I've done in my life has been safe and practical, and where's that gotten me? (she lifts her paper cup)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, here's to who knows what. They touch their cups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a two-story  apartment in a renovated building. It has high ceilings  and exposed brick. It is sparsely- furnished, but what  there is is decent-looking. We see Nora and BB dancing  closely in the shadows of the dark- ened room.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A Frank Sinatra record is playing on the RECORD PLAYER in the b.g. -- it is "IN THE WEE SMALL HOURS OF THE MORNING." A bottle of wine is on the coffee table. The remains of Chinese food in containers are alongside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess that's to be expected. You want me to take you home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not right now. They dance quietly for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time I listen to Sinatra, I always remember when I used to work in Atlantic City back in the late 40's... you know, a busboy job... Sinatra used to play at the 500 Club, and we used to take our dates and say, 'Hey, you wanna go and hear Sinatra?' Then we'd just lean on the door of the club in the alley and listen to the music. I think the girls were looking for something a bit more uptown. Nora laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd go with you and lean against the door. They dance for a bit and look at one another. He leans toward her, holds her tight and kisses her. Then the RECORD STICKS on the words "that's the time"... "that's the time"... "that's the time"... BB slips off one of his loafers, while still embracing Nora, kicks it so that it hits the side of the record table. The RECORD SLIPS a little and continues to play correctly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she looks at BB)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a pretty good aim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sure do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora is sleeping in the bed, BB slips a robe on, looks at her and then goes down the stairs to the living room. He takes a piece of paper out of his jacket pocket on the back of a chair, and dials a number on the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TELEPHONE RINGS at the bar, the BARMAN picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he's here... just a minute. The Barman calls over to Tilley who we see sitting at a table with some of the other tin men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
