dialogues.text: Hey, Tilley, somebody wants ya on the phone. Tilley gets up from the table and goes over to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, this is Tilley...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB on phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, asshole... here's the ultimate 'fuck you'... I just poked your wife!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley on phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB on phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in my bed right now with a big smile on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley on phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's just fine by me... she's a pain in the ass... an albatross around my neck. You're welcome to her... keep her... and may you both rot in hell! Tilley slams the phone down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB puts the phone down -- looks puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this    a setup? That son of a bitch...    I bet he set me up... I thought    I got him, and he got me. That son    of a bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley pulls up in his car in front of his house. runs up the front steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door, flips on the lights and looks around. He races upstairs and starts rifling through the closet and drawers, pulling out Nora's clothes -- her dresses, skirts, blouses, and coats -- and he opens the window wide and throws them out. He screams as he tosses underwear and the rest of her clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a free man! I'm a free man! He grabs Nora's shoes and throws them out onto the street. Then he goes into the bathroom and piles all of her toiletries in his arms, tosses them into a trash can. Takes a suitcase from a shelf in the bedroom, opens it, throws in the trash can. He clears out her underwear drawers and empties them into the suitcase, closes the suitcase and then throws that out of the window. He's out of breath, exhausted and sweating. He goes down- stairs into the kitchen to get himself a drink. He sees a pair of Nora's slippers under the kitchen table, he picks them up, opens the back door and tosses them outside. Locks the door. He stands there as if a motor is running inside of him. Walks out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits the house, gets into his car and drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley is driving.    The same Sinatra record "IN THE WEE SMALL HOURS OF THE   MORNING" is playing on the car RADIO Tilley does his now   familiar neck exercises to relieve tension. He's hard    to read... a mixture of happiness and sadness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH the window of the diner we see Tilley sitting alone at a table drinking a cup of coffee. The Sinatra record "IN THE WEE SMALL HOURS OF THE MORNING" plays over this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora is getting out of her car in front of her house. She starts to walk toward the house and stops as she sees her clothing, shoes, etc. scattered all over the lawn. She tries to take in the scene -- coats are lying on hedges, underwear on the flower beds... she's shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my God! She just stands there and tears run down her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of Nora's BACK TO the CAMERA, with all her possessions strewn over the front garden of her house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora is standing at the door with her suitcase in hand. BB is at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must have gone crazy... I don't know what happened to him... he must have found out I was with you... I don't know... I don't know what to do. She starts to cry.   She goes to hug BB.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I stay with you for a day or two? BB puts his arms around Nora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: of a nearly empty pool hall. One guy plays alone in the far corner of the room. Tilley comes down the stairs of the pool hall and starts to walk toward the back rooms -- CAMERA FOLLOWS him. He opens the door and goes through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA CONTINUES TO FOLLOW him INTO the offices of Gibraltar Aluminum Siding Company.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We PASS BY THREE GIRLS on telephones -- they are solicit- ing jobs for the salesmen. CAMERA GOES FROM one Girl TO the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, this is Gibraltar Aluminum Siding Company, we're taking a survey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Would you be interested in our field representative giving you a home demonstration?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Home demonstration. We will have some factory representatives in your area today as it happens. A voice calls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley!    Let me see you. Tilley walks over to the coffee machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wing, give me a minute to get a cup of coffee here. Tilley passes Sam on the way to the coffee machine. Sam is looking through the sports page of the newspaper, along with Mouse and Gil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about 'Super Highway' in the seventh... it's paying 7 to 1. Ran well in its last race. Gil looking at the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Super Highway'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four in the fourth... twenty bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... it just came to me -- number four in the fourth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at Tilley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number four in the fourth -- 'Rider's Revenge' -- 60 to 1, never been in the money. Nice pick, Tilley. Why don't you just throw the twenty dollars in the trash can right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Rider's Revenge'... I like that name. I've gotta go and see Wing. (a little pissed off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, we can be scientific from now to doomsday, but we gotta be gutsy and go for the big one. Tilley goes through the door into Wing's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His office    is equally messy and thrown together as everything    else in the Gibraltar offices. As Tilley closes the    door, his coffee, which is filled to the to of his cup,    spills over the top and starts to burn his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah!    Ah! He jumps back, and puts his coffee down on a desk, and wipes his hand on the back of his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up, Wing? Wing is sitting at his desk which is cluttered with papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lost a sale, Tilley. The Hudsons' loan didn't go through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do ya mean? They wouldn't clear the loan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This Mr. Hudson's some guy. He's got three outstanding shoplifting charges, failure to pay child support from a previous marriage ... guy's overdue on his mortgage, overdue on his car loan, and he was fired from his last job for misappropriation of funds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with this world? There are sick people out there! Thievin' son of a bitch like that takes up my time... cuts into the amount of hours I have available to deal with other people interested in my wares! There's no fucking sympathy for the working man in this country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't make our job easy, Tilley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lamenting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wing, it was such a beautiful thing... you shoulda seen how I worked. Like a magician... 'this job is free'! It was my best... my best! There's no fucking justice in this world... there ain't no justice. Tilley goes to pick up his coffee off the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see the paper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What section?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a look at this. He hands the newspaper to Tilley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Home Improvement Commission... Hearings begin today..." Is this McCarthyism? What are they gonna see? If there are any communists?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just cool down the scams, okay, Tilley? Tilley shrugs his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An area has been set up for hearings to take place. This seems to be a temporary headquarters until something sub- stantial can be worked out. There are boxes and crates all over. There's a long table with a number of commis- sioners behind it, and a defense table a little way across the room. MICROPHONES are being used, and the sound BOOMS -- ECHOING off the walls. A small gallery of people are watching the proceedings.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN MASTERS
dialogues.text: who is presiding over the hearings. Even though he wears a tie and a vest, he is nonetheless very sloppily dressed To his left and right are two other home improvement commissioners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now,  when you made your initial sales  pitch, did you indicate that  you would be giving free storm  windows with the job?

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY BANKS
dialogues.text: A typical aluminum sidings salesman, in his early 40's. He leans into the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Free storm windows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. That you would provide a free set of storm windows with the sale of aluminum siding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. I wouldn't be able to make any money if I was giving away storm windows. My cost of a storm window is somewhere like...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting him off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point being that you had no intention of giving away the storm windows.

dialogues.speaker: BB AND MOE
dialogues.text: Standing by the door at the back of the warehouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The storm windows, as I can recall, was not an issue. I mentioned that I thought the storm windows would cut down on their heating bill, and that they would obviously enhance the look of the house with the aluminum siding work we were going to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you weren't dangling a free set of storm windows as a come-on to selling them the aluminum siding job? Because it says here, and I'm reading from a statement from Mr. Tabaleri...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to BB)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do ya make of all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the future, Moe... it's the future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'It was my understanding that the storm windows were included in the price of the sale.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moe and BB are walking away from the warehouse toward BB's car... AWAY FROM CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you think they're getting this information from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno... looks like any tin man gets in that hot seat, then he's had it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then they can take your license forever... it don't seem fair. They walk by a Volkswagen "beetle" car that's parked in front of BB's Cadillac. BB stops and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, I tell ya, I bet you could sell a ton of these things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That?   Too silly-looking. BB looks at the car for a few more seconds, then goes to get into his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever see a dealership?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting. They get in the car and drive off.

dialogues.speaker: STARTING GATE
dialogues.text: as it bolts open and the horses charge out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting at a table. Sam is studying the racing form, Tilley is studying the menu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I keep racking my brain. I gotta find a way to really get even with this guy. It isn't enough to wreck his car... even breaking into his house and messing it up or something, that don't have enough impact. I mean, the man poked my wife! I gotta come up with something ingenious... something ingenious. Sam sees a WAITER approaching and indicates to Tilley to get off the subject. Waiter arrives at their table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tilley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what do ya think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll take some meatloaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (writes on check)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meatloaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I think I'll have some fish. No, no... fish doesn't fill you up. Meatloaf. He closes the menu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, it's meatloaf?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tilley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think, 'Sally's pride' in the second? (to Waiter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me a Bloody Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything other than the Bloody Mary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What number is Sally's Pride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six. (to Waiter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't like to eat until the third race. Waiter walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting his hand to his forehead)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six... six... six... six. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking one. Whose one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Motor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then that's it, I'm going with one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley, this is insane. You're picking horses because you think you're clairvoyant or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, I'm  not doing too well by checking  the stats, so why not. I put my  hand to my forehead, I see a one  -- Mr. Motor in the second...  twenty bucks. They both look toward the track, the horses race to the finish line. Number nine streaks across the finish line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hallihan's Daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it... I got it... He picks up the racing form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three to one... hundred and sixty smackers. (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hand to the forehead! Hand to the forehead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not exactly talking about a long shot. Mr. Motor, for instance, is coming off at 50 to 1. Tilley taps his forehead, with his eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Third race, I see a six... I see a three. I don't think the verdict's in on that one yet. Tilley stands up and is going through his money and race tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wing paid a hundred on number five, he loses, I got hundred and forty... next race I'll lay down the bet. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you taking in this   race?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thrifty's Delight -- number four -- 20 bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take Thrifty's Delight -- 20 bucks, I got 20 on Mr. Motor, Wing's got a hundred on Night Fire. What's the odds on Night Fire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty to one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see Night Fire winning. Fuck it, I'm not gonna even place the bet... I just made a hundred bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you, crazy?   What happens if he wins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not gonna win... I feel it.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tilley heads towards the betting booths.    Wing enters near the booths, Tilley yells to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Wing, we're sitting just off the left of the entrance. I'm gonna lay down your bet right now. See you in a minute. You lost the first race, in case you don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB's Cadillac is moving along the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB is behind the wheel, Moe is beside him in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you something, she's getting on my nerves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who, Nora?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah... who else is it gonna be... 'who, Nora"!... who else is there? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole idea of being with a girl on consecutive nights is new to me. It's one thing when they're with you for a night, but when they live with ya, it's stretching the point. They got a lot of things they bring with them... you go to the bathroom you see 'things' you never saw before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what's the todo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they move your stuff around and it's not where it used to be... I'm not used to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean all this time you've never lived with a girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! Did we just meet? How long we been partners? No, I've never lived with a girl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, oh boy! Did you wake up on the wrong side of the bed today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I did. I came in  last night, she was sleeping on my side of the bed. In my life I  never got out of bed on the left side... in my life, never from the left. (beat; he looks out of the car window)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got close once up in the Catskills. I met this  girl, Dorian. For a week we  were together, but it wasn't the same because she always went to her room to change and do all that stuff. She didn't  have things in my room. BB gives a big sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this 'cos I'm trying to get even with some guy. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what? I think I got to see her and put an end to this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see hundreds of secretaries typing away, and clerks sitting at desks. BB walks into the office, peeking his head around the corner, feeling a little uncomfortable. He starts to walk around trying to find Nora out of all the secretaries and clerks.

dialogues.speaker: NELLIE
dialogues.text: Nora's friend. She looks up from the typewriter and sees BB. In his thick overcoat, huddled up, he seems a little lost, and it's obvious that he's looking for someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling across to Nora at the next desk)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up and and BB wandering around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (she smiles and yells)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill! BB turns towards Nora. Nora waves to him, happily, with a twinkle in her eye. BB feels conspicuous -- people are looking at him. He gives a little wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora gives BB a small kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you stopped by.     This is a real surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I got a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.    How can I help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... er... (realizing    that she didn't quite get    the point)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the problem    is... like... is like... eh, you    know... you're the problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, obviously really taken with him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. How so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's things that are bothering me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know... things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, like things that come up... stuff... like... you know, annoyances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annoyances?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to explain... very hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As an example... I came home last night, I get undressed, and I realize you're sleeping on my side of the bed. I've always slept on that side... it's something I've always done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why didn't you just nudge me a bit and tell me to go and sleep on the other side?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to wake you up... I thought you might think it was kind of stupid or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's easily changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there are other things... bigger things. But I realize just talking about it, they all sound petty and silly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, if you think all of this is going too fast, maybe I should move out. Is that what you want, Bill? BB looks around, very uncomfortable, and he shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really care for you, but if you think it's best. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to make you unhappy. After a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think we've got to take drastic action. Nora smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought I'd come by and get things off my chest... talk it out. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I'm going over to Pimlico... catch the seventh race... wanna come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't get away from work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. He goes to walk away, then turns back and gives her a quick kiss. He turns and walks away. Nora watches him as he walks by the rows and rows of secretaries and clerks.

dialogues.speaker: TILLEY
dialogues.text: watching a race.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very excited and animated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're taking a thirty-to-one shot... number eight... come on number eight... 'Streamers...' come on, you sucker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see horse number eight in the lead, coming around the home stretch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moe and BB are watching the race.

dialogues.speaker: TILLEY, SAM AND WING
dialogues.text: Tilley is still yelling for his horse, Sam and Wing watch quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-to-one... a hundred bucks on you, number eight. There's a guy up here who put a hundred on ya. Come on... come on... come on, baby... come on, baby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another horse -- number 14 -- races past the winning post.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nooooooo!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Wing smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got myself a winner. Tilley turns to look at Wing. Sam turns towards Tilley looking concerned. We see the totals flashed on the board indicating that the winning horse pays $16.30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Way to go... Southern Belle. Moe tears up his ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should have bet with me, Moe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very nice!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was your horse, Wing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... Southern Belle. You oughta know, you bet her for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Wing goes to look at form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tilley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna go with the favorite in this one -- Fordnee Lane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you what, I    won sixteen plus on the other    race, from those winnings you    can bet me eight hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight hundred?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... I wanna bet eight hundred on Fordnee Lane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeling uncom- fortable)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fordnee lane -- eight hundred. Sam is looking at Tilley knowing that he's really in a jam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling to Waiter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiter, can you get me a cup of coffee? Tilley looks over to Sam, with panic on his face.    Wing turns back to Tilley and Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys want anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods "no")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er... hum... er... hey, Wing... I tell you, I got a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the eight hundred on Fordnee Lane. I haven't got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you got it wrong. You take it from the sixteen plus I won... the eight hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't got the winnings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do ya mean, you don't have my winnings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wing, it was the craziest thing... I didn't want to mention it earlier because it was so nuts... it was the craziest thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how to even tell you this without being embarrassed for myself. It was an accident... it's like one of those things out of the blue... it's crazy... you can't explain it... it happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, what is he talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had an accident of some sort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It happens... I don't know how... I don't know how to explain. It's too crazy, I swear to God, Wing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute... you're telling me that I didn't win the last race?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won, Wing... you won, it's just that you're not getting any money... it was a fluke. I swear, I don't know how it could have happened. A ten-year-old couldn't have made the mistake I made... I don't know, I swear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck is he talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there was some way I could make it up, believe me, I would, because you know where I stand. There's a beat while Wing just looks at Tilley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where I stand, Wing. If there was any way, believe me, I'd make it up. I'd give you thirty percent of what you didn't get because it was a fluke... I'm willing to make some kind of retribution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just pocketed the God damned money... you just took my money and slipped it into your God damned pocket, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'd split fifty-fifty with you, that's how badly I feel under the circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get this straight, you son of a bitch, you owe me sixteen plus... I want sixteen plus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I trying to shirk my responsibility? That's not the way I see it... it was a fluke, a crazy thing that happened, but I stand behind my honor on this... put it on my tab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What  the hell is wrong with him? What  the hell is wrong with him? He's  stealing money from me... what  the hell is wrong with him? Can  you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know the whole story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You work with him, Sam... for Christ sake... Wing is totally frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, wrong? It was a fluke... it was an accident. I don't know what the hell went wrong. It was a one-in-a-million thing that happened to me when I went to place that bet. I'm trying to do what I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley, what the hell happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley and Sam are leaving the racetrack and walking to Tilley's Cadillac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you at least give him the six hundred that you pocketed from the six races he lost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck him! It's on my tab. At least I've got six hundred in my pocket right now. It's like another loan. Sam, you got to think about today. Today, I got six hundred bucks in my pocket. You know what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like some guy trying to sell me life insurance. You think I'm gonna take some money out of my pocket to give to some jerk so that somebody can take it when I'm dead? No, Sam, you gotta live for today. I'm gonna live as good as I can every day. You know what I'm saying? As Sam and Tilley walk towards Tilley's Cadillac, BB and Moe are walking to BB's Cadillac parked close to Tilley's car. They see each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling to BB)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Mr. Marengay went to the track!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you bother to bet, or did you just hand your money to the tellers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sarcasm's killing me. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were looking to get even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's your accountant, mister, 'cos I think you're down in the debit side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's stuck with my wife.   You or me? He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to believe that you were setting me up with your wife as some kind of decoy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Decoy is the word! There's a long beat as the two guys eye one another. Then, almost in a soft apologetic manner, BB speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay then, you win. BB gets into his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I win? (to Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That guy would never let me win. He must be setting me up. The son of a bitch is setting me up, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For crying out loud, why don't you just leave it at that... you win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't have won. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I smell a rat. BB's car pulls away.    Tilley and Sam watch him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB's driving and Moe is in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB, I think you're getting a little humility in your blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If getting Nora is part of losing, Thank God I didn't win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A temporary sign is posted on the door and a painter is filling in the name -- "HOME IMPROVEMENT COMMISSION."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the office of the Home Improvement Commission. Desks, chairs and filing cabinets are all over the place (not yet organized) and boxes and cartons are stacked against a wall. ANGLE ON John Masters walking with a file under his arm. He walks across the half-empty warehouse where workers are renovating the space. He approaches a table where Stanley is seated with his feet up, nursing a hot cup of coffee. Masters throws a file down on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is good, Stan... nice work. Stanley nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fossey says it should go down very well with the city council. Could help us appropriate more funds. This goes a long way to establish our credibility in what we're trying to do. We hear a LOUD, SAWING noise and HAMMERING echoing through the warehouse throughout this scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a lot more where this came from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I think you should do now. Why don't you pull some files... some files that were completed, others that went unsold, and I'll have somebody run it down, talk to the customers and get some statements.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulling files is another thing. That might not be easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To sneak a few here and there when you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that might be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB's Cadillac is parked in front of a house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think if we made this one of our factory showcase houses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a good location... get a lot of traffic on this street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB and Moe are selling to MR. and MRS. SHUBNER, a young couple. The TELEVISION is ON in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean, Mr. Gable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I do, Alan? I pick certain houses that are strategically located, we put up the aluminum siding, and for every referral, for every person who sees this quality job that we do... sees how beautiful it is... I give you two hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hundred dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. God knows how many homes we could sell by people passing this house. It's perfectly placed for that. (taking out his wallet)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan, this is how confident I feel that this house will drum up business for me. He peels off four hundred dollars and hands the money to Shubner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four hundred dollars... I'm giving you commission on two house referrals before I put a panel on the side of your house... that's how confident I feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think that many people are going to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting Shubner)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm certain of it. I'm not giving away four hundred dollars for my health... I'm a businessman, and I'm a good businessman. This is good business for me. I'm giving it away 'cos I believe in this house, believe that it will refer me to other jobs which means money in my pocket, which means money in your pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a deal, Mr. Gable. BB smiles.   Suddenly Moe winces in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something wrong, sir? Moe collapses to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moe is being wheeled on a gurney by a couple of nursing attendants. BB walks alongside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I finally got hold of May... she was over your sister's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathing heavily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I forgot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be down here shortly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB, I don't have any insurance. If I die, May's got nothing... nothing... nothing for Leonard. The only money I've got is in my pocket. That's all I got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just take it easy, Moe... rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did they sign?     Did they sign?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn it, BB! Did you sign them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry... don't worry.     I'll take care of it tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn, my chest hurts. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always taught you, BB, never walk out of a place without a signed contract. Somebody's word ain't spit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll sign, Moe.    Don't worry, they'll sign. They round the bend of the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB is on a public phone to Nora.     We never see Nora, w just hear her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is kind of   new to me, but I thought I better   call and tell you I'm gonna be   late... maybe two or three. I    never had anyone there to   call before, but I thought I   should call, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Do you think you have some obligation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno... I thought I'd better call, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm glad you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what's gonna happen to Moe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I hope he's okay. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you when you get in. She gives BB a kiss on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at the receiver)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He hangs up the phone and walks to a room opposite. He opens the door and stands in the doorway looking at Moe who is lying beneath an oxygen tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley, Sam, Mouse and Gil are sitting in a booth having just finished breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see what the damage is. (he reaches for the bill, hums as he reads)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babum... babum... babum... babum... He hands the bill to Mouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mouse, figure it out, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we just split it five ways?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way! I didn't eat anything, so why should I pay for Mouse... he eats like an animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sometimes you'll eat more than he does, and it'll even out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way! He's a pig! He always eats more than anyone else. Why should I pay for his food?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you talking about? Today I happened to have eggs and flapjacks, some cantalope, some juice and then another juice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like an animal! Like an animal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But yesterday, what did I have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he have? (turning to Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, what did he have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get out my notebook. How the fuck do I know what he had?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I don't remember what he had. Gil, what did he have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancakes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Through the diner window we see Nora's car pull up and park outside the diner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mouse)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what did you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, a quiz show? We don't know what you had. What did you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had very little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very little!! You eat like an animal! It couldn't have been very little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't have that much... doesn't anybody remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't remember, I don't know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could have sworn he had pancakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he didn't have pancakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you a clue... maple syrup was used.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't give a shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: French toast. There's a KNOCK at the window of the diner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: French toast?    He had more than French toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but not a lot more. We hear further RAPPING on the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't give a damn... it's split five ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tilley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your wife's knocking on the window here. Tilley looks to the window, acknowledges Nora and points to the far end of the diner, she nods and starts walking across the front of the diner to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora and Tilley are sitting alone at a table drinking coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was not long ago you never would have seen a woman in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to tell me. How many nights did you drop me off and come up here all the time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I was just trying to be congenial... you know, start a conversation off, on a nice kind of light level, you know. So, what's the scoop, Nora?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you know, I think we really should get divorced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makes sense.   You want some more coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'll have some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting to waitress)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Florence, some coffee here. (to Nora)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's for the best. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, we were kind of fooling ourselves, weren't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it went wrong somewhere along the line -- I don't know where though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, something went wrong... I don't know. Florence walks over and pours coffee for Tilley and Nora, then walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you like this guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All in all I guess it'll all work out for the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you feel that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, can you figure it out? A guy bangs into my car, thinks I did him in, tries to get even with me by stealing my wife, you two people fall in love... can you figure that out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You telling me you didn't know this was the guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was that guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I told you I ran into another tin man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't tell me he was a tin man... he told me he sold baby pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your life. All I know is this guy has a bent weather vane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God!   Not another tin man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see and hear the Girls working the telephones, as before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, this is Superior Aluminum Siding. We're going to have...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... a salesman in your area today... BB is sitting in a chair across from Looney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beeb, why don't you let Stanley work with you. I'm off to Florida at the end of the week for some sun and fun. Let Stanley work with you, and when I get back, we'll see how Moe's doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. To be honest with you, I think I'd rather work alone ... he's too green. Is he a pain in the ass?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He don't talk much; he's a good listener, so he can't really get on your nerves. He's a lousy pool player and he can't play cards for shit, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what good is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Studious type... takes a lot of notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this is a sales pitch, I think you got to work a little harder 'cos I don't think you've got good product.

dialogues.speaker: BB
dialogues.text: As he comes out of the Superior Aluminum building and walks towards his car. We see Nora driving her Chevy in front of BB's car. She drives her car forward, and then reverses it hard into BB's Cadillac. He runs over to the driver's side of Nora's Chevy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you, crazy?! Nora drives the car forward and then backwards again almost running BB down. She rolls down the window (auto- matically) so that she can yell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a goddamn tin man! Then she backs the car up.      BB tries to go around the front of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute!     Wait a minute! Nora starts to move the car towards him. He moves away, and her car smashes into the side of his car. She presses the button to the window and rolls it down just a shade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to win me just to get even with my husband... screw you! She rolls up the window, floors the car, and drives away.

dialogues.speaker: LOONEY
dialogues.text: as he walks out of the building.   He sees BB's car all smashed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to BB)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you ought to get rid of this car... it's bad luck. Nora's CAR SCREECHES around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the guy again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's some kind of sickness that runs in that family.

dialogues.speaker: MOUSE
dialogues.text: He's singing "The Banana Boat Song."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Day-O! da,da,da,da,day... daylight come and he wanna go home...'

dialogues.speaker: TILLEY AND GIL
dialogues.text: at a table playing pool. Mouse is standing next to his trusted JUKEBOX, belting out his favorite Harry Belafonte song. In b.g.:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gil)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't they get rid of that fucking record? It's not a hit anymore... nobody cares about this song anymore... it's history. Mouse continue singing in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Day-O!   da,da,da,da,day...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can always smash the juke box, or break in and steal the record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lining up a shot)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's getting on my nerves. The guy eats like an animal, and sings like an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's me, but I'm beginning to like it. Tilley hits the ball and sinks the shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir... yes, sir!

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: He comes out of the back room into the pool hall, and walks over to the table where Tilley and Gil are playing pool. He drops an open envelope onto the pool table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tilley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a look at this crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IRS? They're not gonna leave me alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home Improvement Commission. With those words there's a genuine moment of concern from all of the tin men -- even Mouse stops singing. Tilley picks up the envelope and pulls out the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got to appear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that's the gist of what they're saying. Gil looks over Tilley's shoulder at the letter.    Mouse comes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy Christ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't we just ignore it? How do they know we got the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's certified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think, Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno... I don't know what they've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is this happening? Am I paranoid or something? I mean, why is this happening? The government is after me... the state is after me... Mr. Marengay ... somebody is always after me. What the hell's going on here? I'm just this guy. What's the big deal? They can't get along without me? The government can't operate unless they've got Tilley's money... the Commission's after my job! This shit's driving me insane! All the lying, thieving, stealing corporations in this world, and the IRS takes the time to come for me? There's billions of dollars out there but they've got to come and get Tilley's four thousand dollars! (turning to Mouse)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn off the fucking Belafonte song now, or I'm gonna break the goddamn machine!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB is sitting at the bar, getting drunk. Stanley sits next to him. A girl approaches (RUTHIE).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Beeb, let's dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not tonight, Ruthie, my dancing shoes are on holiday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm more than sure. Ruthie moves off. BB takes a shot of whiskey and downs it, and then drinks some beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was the best you ever saw?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best I ever saw?   Best tin man I ever saw? He holds up his shot glass towards the bartender, and the bartender fills it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry Apel... Dandy Flynn... those guys had good lines, but they burned themselves out too fast. Best? Moe's the best... the best there ever was. If he's in the door, he's got a sale. The best closer ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's some of the hustles he used to pull? BB downs another shot glass of whisky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn Nora... God damn Nora! I'm trying to adjust... I'm putting up with things I never put up with in my life. I mean, give me a break... give me a break, woman. Stanely wants to get back to the topic of best tin man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making light)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what are a couple of things you and Moe have done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still on the subject of Nora)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was getting to be real pleasant ... figure that. (long beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More than pleasant. To hell with her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come Moe's so good?   Why do you think, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great man, Moe. Great man. BB holds out his glass again to the bartender who refills it. BB downs the shot and drinks more beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why they're so irrational... chicks. I dunno. I think it's because air gets inside 'em. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She probably went back home, to her husband. (looks at his watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleven-thirty... he wouldn't be home yet. (takes out a $10 bill from his wallet)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This outght to cover it, Stanley. He puts the $10 bill down on the bar and walks out of the club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam's Cadillac moving along a row of houses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam is driving the car, Tilley is in the passenger seat, very drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got no right. You know what I'm saying, Sam? They've got no right. Tilley takes a drink from a pint of whisky he has open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've got nothing concrete against us, because if it's just hearsay stuff, it's neither here nor there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around) Where's my car? What happened to my car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's better I drop you off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley is    in the    bathroom washing his    face in th trying to    sober    up. He lifts his head     out of th and bangs    it on    the faucet. He grabs     his head i and then    slides    down the tiled wall to    the floor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB's Cadillac pulls up in front of Tilley's house. We see BB looking up and down the street, with his head out of the car window. He's very drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets out of the car and looks around the street some more. He stumbles up to a couple of parked cars, look- ing for Nora's car. He falls into some trash cans in front of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley    is lying on the floor. His eyes open at the sou of the    TRASH CANS FALLING. He struggles to his feet an walks    through the bedroom. We hear the sound of MORE TRASH    CANS RATTLING.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tilley goes to the bedroom window and looks out. He sees BB struggling to his feet, surrounded by trash cans and garbage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew I    could smell a rat! The son of a    bitch is coming for me... the son    of a bitch never wants to leave me    alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley walks over to the night table, opens the drawer and pulls out a revolver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB making his way up the front stairs to Tilley's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley makes his way down the stairs, and creeps to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) You   want to rob my God damn house? I'm   gonna make it easy for you. (unlocks the door and leaves it ajar) Come   and rob Tilley... come on... take   everything he's got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB knocks on the door. The door swings open.      He wait a moment, unsure as to what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley stands behind the door with the gun, waiting. steps inside the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hel... Before he can finish the word "Hello," Tilley hits him hard in the head with the butt of the gun. BB falls to the ground unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACK SCREEN. Then a light goes on, and we see the in- side of a refrigerator. PULL BACK to reveal Tilley at the refrigerator in the kitchen of his home. He is putting eggs and rotten tomatoes from the refrigerator into a bowl. He looks at a piece of celery, but it's so wilted and has no strength for his purpose that he throws it down. He picks up other vegetables, but settles for the eggs and tomatoes. He closes the re- frigerator door and makes his way to the living room. We see BB lying on the floor, unconscious. Tilley sits down across from him with the bowl in his lap... he watches BB. BB starts to come to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to BB)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a sick man! You smash my car, you steal my wife, and now you come to rob me! You're one demented human being. BB tries to focus on Tilley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to call the police and send you to jail... but I'm going to humiliate you first. Tilley throws an egg at BB and hits him in the head. is groggy and confused and still drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do ya want to break into my house for? This ain't the fucking Rockefeller mansion! There ain't thirty-eight television sets here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ain't saying 'Nelson, I think we've had a break-in... count the sets to see how many we've got left.' There ain't tons of jewelry hanging out of drawers... it ain't like I don't know which watch to put on, I got so many. I'm a working man, trying to make an honest living. What fucking morality you got, asshole?!! Tilley throws another egg at BB and hits him in the head again. Egg yolk drips down BB's face. He tries to get off the floor, but can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the craziest human being on the face of this earth! Tilley, getting ready with another egg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else do you want from me? Huh? What else?! I've got enough problems with the I.R.S. busting my balls and the Home Improvement Commission bullshit to contend with. I don't need aggravation from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still trying to get up; wiping his face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody does this to me and lives! Nobody!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throws an egg)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do ya like your eggs? Over easy? (picks up a tomato)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Side of tomatoes? He throws a tomato.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to rue the day you ran into my car. This ain't the end... this is just the beginning. Tilley throws another egg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A POLICE OFFICER is interrogating Tilley behind the main desk of the police station. There's a lot of activity during this interaction... people coming and going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guy breaks into my house and I'm being charged with assault? It makes no sense...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with pencil and paper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get it down right. The guy broke into your house, you hit him in the head with a gun, went to the refrigerator, took out eggs and tomatoes and threw them at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was defending myself... he was stealing from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't sound like defense to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to humiliate the guy. Here I am, out busting my ass all day making a decent living, I come home, and some schmuck is trying to steal from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you hit him with a gun, and pelted him with eggs and tomatoes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I had some soup I would have thrown soup at him... is there any law you can't throw eggs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Babowski claims he didn't break into your house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I do? Invite him in so that I could throw eggs at him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe Mr. Babowski intended to break into your house, but these circumstances of the guy being pelted with eggs and tomatoes is something we need to look into. Tilley shrugs his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's lucky that he didn't rob me last week, 'cos then my wife was living at home and we had all kinds of things in the fridge... I could have thrown barley soup, pumpkin pie, candied yams... yeah, he got off light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley and Sam exit the building. Seconds later BB and Bagel come out of the police station. Both pair of men head for their respective Cadillacs. BB has egg stains all over his suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bagel)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe it, the man throws eggs at me and now I'm gonna have breakfast with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His partner says maybe the two of you can sit down and come to some kind of settlement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley is sitting in the driver's seat and Sam is next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to say to him? The man has been a pain in the ass since the day he rammed into my car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just air your differences and we'll put an end to this.

dialogues.speaker: TWO CADILLACS
dialogues.text: as they start to pull out of the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley, Sam, BB and Bagel are sitting at a table together looking at menus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up from his menu)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you what... I'll drop the charges against you, and we can wipe the slate clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See how quickly you can clear it up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't understand how the slate gets wiped clean when he breaks into my house and I'm the one charged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, I wasn't breaking into your house. I was looking for your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right... all right... I'm too tired... the slate's clean... the slate's clean. The WAITRESS approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couple of eggs over,   some hash browns, some toast --   toasted dark... butter on the   side, large grapefruit juice and   some coffee. The Waitress writes his order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On second thought, instead of the eggs over, if I ordered soft boiled eggs do you take them out of the shell or leave them in the shells? We can see that BB is getting a little irritable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We leave them in the shell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like them that way because they get hot in the hand and it's hard to scoop the stuff out... it's not good... and you get little bits of shell in there and it doesn't taste good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you just order some scrambled eggs and be done with it... all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'm going to order, at least I ought to be content with my food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting a little hungry... I've got a headache as it is. Just order some eggs so some other people can have something to eat before the lunch trade comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks to Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do I need a guy telling me what I should or shouldn't eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not a four-star restaurant ... we're not having a gourmet meal... we're ordering breakfast, for Christ sake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It so happens I haven't been to this restaurant before. I don't know how they do their eggs... if they're over easy and they're gooey, I'm not happy with it... and I'm not happy if the soft boiled eggs are left in the shell...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Waitress, cutting Tilley off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have some French toast and a cup of coffee? (to Bagel)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bagel, what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! I'm ordering here. At least you can have the courtesy to let a man order his breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Waitress; ignoring Tilley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: French toast and a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, this guy gets on my nerves... from day one! I knew it then and I know it now. Tilley stands up from the table and starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm back to pressing charges against you! Tilley turns and is face-to-face with BB.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to play that way? This game ain't over, mister... it ain't over...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BB stands up.   The Waitress steps back and looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, you want to finish it now? You want to finish it right now? I'm ready... I'm ready now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're ready?! You're ready, that's what you're saying?! You're ready now?! I have to be intimidated... I have to be brought here to be intimidated...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't stand it any longer. You're driving me out of my mind. BB lunges for Tilley across the table, Sam and Bagel try to intervene -- the Waitress doesn't know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, guys... take it easy... take it easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the people with the straitjackets... this man is out of control. Tilley and BB pull at one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna finish it... we're gonna finish it. Bagel and Sam pull them apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tilley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, let's get out of here. Sam ushers Tilley to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not finished with him, Sam. (to BB)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard me... I'm not finished with you, mister.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He storms out of the coffee shop with Sam. Bagel sits back, looking relieved. BB composes himself. The Waitress nervously stands by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Waitress)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, I'm having French toast and coffee. (to Bagel)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bagel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moe is in bed, still hooked up to tubes. His breathing is deliberate and he seems weak. The CAMERA SLOWLY PANS TO BB who is sitting by Moe's side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moe, when you decided to marry May, how did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did ya know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean to make up my mind to marry her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.     How did ya know? Moe shrugs his shoulders as if he doesn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly angry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This Nora is a pain in the ass, Moe... a pain in the ass. It's worse now than when she used to be around. Moe smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna hear something? The other night at the Corral Club, I turned down a dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You turned down a dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the odds on that? You think you can come up with odds on that one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundred to one BB don't dance... a hundred to one against. There's a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting out of the business, BB... I've got nothing for all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lot of good times, Moe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of good times, but I can't live off the good times. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, my brother-in-law has offered me a job at Hess Shoes. I think maybe I should do it. You get there in the morning, you come home at night... you get health benefits... I get to be assistant manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it, Moe? You're gonna spend the day measuring people's feet? 'You're an "E" fit... you're a "D" wide... you got a high arch... I'll show you something in an alligator... something with a wing tip...' How can you talk about that all day long? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moe, you're the best tin man there ever was. Nobody's a better closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's over, BB... it's over.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BB looks at Moe for a long beat.   He's obviously greatly affected by this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, May's happy about this Hess Shoe thing, heh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To say the least.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam is driving and Tilley is in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, when I saw 'Bonanza' the other day, something occurred to me. There's those three guys living on the Ponderosa and you never hear them say anything about wanting to get laid. You never hear Hoss turn to Little Joe and say 'I had such a hard-on when I woke up this morning.' You know ... they never talk about broads ... nothing. Ya never hear Little Joe say 'Hey, Hoss, I went into Virginia City and saw a girl with the greatest ass I ever saw in my life.' Ya just see 'em walking around the Ponderosa saying, 'Yes, Pa,' and 'Where's Little Joe?' Nothing about broads. I don't think I'm being too picky... at least once if they talked about getting horny. I don't care if you're living on the Ponderosa or right here in Baltimore, guys talk about getting laid. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm beginning to think that show doesn't have too much realism. What do you think, Tilley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, I can't concentrate on 'Bonanza' shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got too much on my brain, what with that asshole and the Home Improvement Commission, I don't want to have to worry about whether Little Joe got laid last night. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go and eat something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we'll go and have some lunch at the smorgasbord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley and Sam are in line at the buffet. Sam fills up his tray and moves off to the cashier. Tilley hangs behind staring at all the food. He looks up to the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, if you're responsible for all the stuff down here, maybe you got a moment's attention for me. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Between the I.R.S., this Home Improvement Commission and Mr. Marengay, I got it up to here with this bullshit. To be frank with you, I'm in the toilet here. If you can see your way... A WOMAN with a tray starts to approach Tilley.     Tilley turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I'm praying here... go around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to get some of the salad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's out of order... go around. He signals for her to walk around him.   The Woman looks at him and moves down the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up to ceiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do what you can, all right?    I appreciate it. Amen. Tilley helps himself to some salad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The usual office activity.   BB is at a desk.   He picks up the phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora Tilley, please. We hear a WOMAN'S VOICE on the other end of the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What department is she with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's with Social Security.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which department is Social Security?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno... she's there somewhere ... yeah, on the third floor... she's got a desk towards the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a moment... checking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the b.g. Stanley has gone over to a filing cabinet and is starting to look through the files. Cheese wanders over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley, can I help you look for something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm just making myself busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I wouldn't do that. Bagel don't like nobody looking at the files.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO BB
dialogues.text: on phone. He's still holding for Nora.    We hear a RING on the other end of the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Tilley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora, this is BB. The PHONE goes DEAD.   BB reluctantly puts the receiver down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Home Improvement Commission is in session. Tilley and Sam sit at the defense table. Masters presides over the commission table where four or five other commis- sioners sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into microphone to Tilley & Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you approach Mr. Boloshevski August 18, 1961, while he was cutting his front lawn and tell him that his house had been selected, as one of only 16 homes in the state of Maryland, for a free aluminum siding job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the name again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boloshevski.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't ring a bell. (to Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, does it ring a bell to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leans into microphone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't ring a bell to me either, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you suggest that for a nominal labor charge, he would receive over five thousand dollars' worth of aluminum siding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's an awful lot for nothing. Doesn't sound like good business to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Boloshevski was ultimately charged twenty-four hundred dollars for labor, which according to our figures is about the average cost of an aluminum siding job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leans into the microphone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get the point of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-four hundred dollars that you charged for labor, is the same as if Mr. Boloshevski had purchased the aluminum siding and had the labor done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'm missing the point here, but if he paid twenty-four hundred, which is the cost of the job, I can't see anything wrong with that. I don't know the guy, but I don't quite get the problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we're getting at here... what we're trying to stress, is that the job was sold under false terms. The man didn't win any award... he was not getting aluminum siding at a special price. A clear case of deception was involved here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he talking about? The man got the job for twenty-four hundred dollars, and that's what it costs in aluminum siding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leans into microphone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... I don't know... we have no recollection of this particular job, but I don't know if this is deception. Look, if you work in a clothing store, some guy tries on a suit, it looks like shit, but you tell him it looks wonderful. The guy's standing there looking like a sack of shit, the salesman says what a great suit and the man buys it. That's deception as far as I can see, but I don't understand the deceptiveness that you say we're responsible for... if I make myself clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning into the microphone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd go along with that as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we're trying to establish are the principles that have been laid down as part of the Home Improvement code of ethics... that you cannot mislead someone intentionally, and I think that's the principle that applies to this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did somebody put a gun to this guy's head and make him spend twenty-four hundred dollars? I don't get the point here. I don't know the specifics of this case, not being privy to all the information, but all I can say is this guy got a fair price for a fair job. Another commissioner, BUD DELANEY, takes the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tilley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know Mr. and Mrs. Rayburn of 156 Aberdeen Avenue, Essex?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks to Sam and shrugs his shoulders; then into mike)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'd have to familiarize me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
