dialogues.text: The couple purchased twenty-eight hundred dollars' worth of aluminum siding and the two of you were the salesmen on record. They say, and I quote here, 'that they would have received one hundred and fifty dollars per home for every person in the neighborhood who saw their house and decided to buy aluminum siding.' (looking up from paper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounds right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you aware that, according to the Home Improvement code, you are not allowed to exceed a twenty dollar limit in incentives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs his shoulders)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wanted to be a little more generous, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The couple said that they never did receive any money from any other jobs, as you had promised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning into microphone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't get any leads from them. Their house was not the showplace that we thought it would be. It didn't generate the activity that we had hoped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But should a referral turn up in the community, we'd be more than happy to give them twenty dollars instead of the hundred and fifty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning into microphone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse us for one moment. He then leans over to Delaney, and they start to confer. Tilley and Sam watch, wondering what's going on. Masters leans in the other direction, holding his hand over the microphone, and he talks to the other commissioners. They nod in approval, then Masters leans back into the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, gentlemen. Should there be a reason in the future to call you back, we would like to reserve that right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leans into microphone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad we could be of some service. Tilley and Sam get up from the table and walk out of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley and Sam are walking toward Tilley's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rubbing his hands, gleefully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We beat 'em, Sam... we beat 'em! What a piece of cake! No problem! They ain't got nothing on us... clean as a whistle... we're clean as a whistle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a drink. I hate inquisitions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavy RAIN is falling. Nora, with an umbrella, walks quickly across the parking lot. Suddenly BB slips under the umbrella with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reacting sharply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to see you anymore. She pulls away from BB and continues walking.      BB wal behind her, getting soaked in the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a chance to explain.    You owe me that much. Nora still walking toward her car in the downpour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't owe you anything. BB lets her walk away.   After a beat, he yells out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a lousy thing to do, okay? It was a lousy thing to use you to get back at your husband... but the fact is that I never would have met you otherwise. Nora stops and turns to look at BB.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was lousy... it was a disgusting, terrible thing... but a lot of good came out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of a person would come up with such a devious thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not always a nice guy, I admit that. I got a lot of training in deceit... it's an occupational hazard. They stand looking at one another in the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to know what it is about me that I have to fall for tin men. What kind of character flaw do I have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to have to come here. I wish that I didn't have to ever see you again. I've gone this far in my life without having to have this kind of thing happen to me. I was going through life, sailing along, pretty good... doing okay, and I tried to get even with some crazy guy... and I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wet becomes you. Gets rid of some of the slickness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like the idea that I'm not in control of this, but if this stuff's got to happen, I guess I've got no choice. I wanna... ya know... (he gets angry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I wanna be with ya! Okay, I said that... I said it, okay?! I wanna be with ya! It pisses the hell out of me, and I'm gonna tell you that to your face, but I want to be with you because... I miss you and I'd like to live with you... I'd like to marry you... and that's that! Nora eyes him carefully. The rain falls on her umbrella and the rain beats on BB's head. After a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping for something a little more romantic... but, okay. A slight smile comes to BB's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley and Sam are sitting at the bar  nursing a couple of drinks. In the b.g., the pianist   is playing "Last Night When We Were Young," and a few  people are sitting around the piano joining in with the  song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya know, Tilley, we been working together for over a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, must be about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been thinking that sometimes a different combination makes for better luck. Ya know what I mean? I mean, maybe the two of us ain't the right combination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just getting used to ya, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's face it, we're not exactly setting the world on fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a slump... it's a slump, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's a slump, but like baseball, some time they have to change the lineup to get the team going again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not serious about this, are you, Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're serious? You wanna get another partner? You don't think I'm gonna pull out of this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're gonna... I know you're gonna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, we beat the   Commission today ... you know, we   got a little bit of a victory.  We   split right now and maybe we can   add to that... you know what I'm   saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know... I know. Change in the lineup. Okay, maybe it'll help... maybe it'll help. (he drinks his whiskey)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got any ideas for a new partner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I had a    conversation with Solly Shavitz,    so... maybe I'll go with him. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mouse is gonna   need a new partner because Dennis   is going into used cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mouse! Mouse! He gets on my nerves... He eats too much. (beat; he holds up his whiskey glass)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's to some pretty good times, huh? Sam smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looney, looking tanned, sits with Stanley at the bar. BB and Nora are dancing in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it... the broad smashes into his car and he takes her dancing. Some kind of dating ritual that I'm not familiar with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB's a pretty good tin man, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty good? Whew! Man's what legends are made of. Started selling pots and pans door to door at sixteen. Nothing he can't sell.

dialogues.speaker: BB AND NORA
dialogues.text: The song ends and BB walks Nora back to the table they were sitting at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna come back and stay the night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno... all my things are back at Nellie's -- the other side of town. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I could do, I'll go back to the house... there's still a few things I left behind ... at least I can get a change of clothes. They both sit down.    BB looks at Nora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad this is working out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't really show a great deal of exuberance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, for me... I'm a parade.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Rattling a special padlock. PULL BACK to reveal Tilley at his front door, trying to get in.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS to see Nora's car pulling up in front of the house. Nora turns off the car lights and exits the car. She starts up the front walk and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The I.R.S... they need my furniture. They got some living room somewhere in this country that needs to be furnished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're taking the furniture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The furniture, the whole house. They locked it up... they confiscated it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling up to him on the porch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you expect? You expect to get some preferential treatment ... you're some special case? You've got to pay your taxes just like everybody else has to pay their taxes! Tilley shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many arguments did we used to have about filing your taxes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had a lot of arguments. Nora starts toward him.     Tilley sits on the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she sits beside him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a responsibility that you've got to have. It's a long way from high school, Tilley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I  was doing pretty good there for a  while... doing pretty good. Had my  house, had a wife, a Cadillac... I  still got my Cadillac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you gonna sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll stay at Sam's for a couple of days until I get set up. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you doing here, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's just a couple of things you didn't throw out of the house ... a couple of things I didn't find in the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... I did a pretty good house cleaning number on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, about the divorce. Do you want to file, or should I file?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to be frank with you, this guy is nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told me all about it... all about how you threw eggs at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told you it was about eggs? The guy tried to break into my house. He tried to steal things from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was trying to find me.    We had an argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'd be making a big mistake if you married him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not for you to make decisions for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think maybe I should, because I think you're being misled... I think you're confused. I think...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I'm doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting Nora)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora, listen to me. I know about guys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting him off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate your concern, but it's not for you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this guy is as bad a choice as you could make. Bad choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good one to give advice... you're sitting on the steps, locked out of your house because you can't pay your taxes, and you're going to give me advice on life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not giving you a divorce, and that's it. I'm looking out for your welfare. No divorce. Nora looks at him, starts to say something, then stands up and walks down the steps of the house toward her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling to her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's for your own benefit, and you'll thank me for it. Nora turns toward Tilley and suddenly snaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My benefit! You don't give a damn about me! You don't give a damn who I marry. The reason you don't want me to marry is because he's the one taking your wife, and you've got your own problems with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't care about me... it's the same bullshit you're doing. That's what it always is with you, Tilley. It's always you! The I.R.S. took your house... your furniture! You don't say anything about my things in the house. I've got things in the house I worked damn hard for, and things that belonged to my family... the headboard that was given to me by Aunt Josephine, it's got to be at least a hundred years old... and the hand-embroidered footstool...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What footstool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hand-embroidered footstool over by the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember seeing that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been there forever... it was my granny's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been there forever?   I've never seen it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never seen it!? You've never seen it!? You put your feet on it to watch TV... the hand-embroidered footstool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking about. I never put my feet up to watch TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the way you are, Tilley, it doesn't mean anything to you. You don't care if they take it all away. It's all you, Tilley! That's the way it's always been.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She stands there for a moment, then turns back to her car, gets in, slams the door and drives off. Tilley stands on the front steps with a puzzled look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hand-embroidered footstool? He walks over to his car, gets in and STARTS the ENGINE.. shaking his head in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB drives up to the building in his Cadillac, the pas- senger door opens and Stanley gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the lift back, BB. See ya around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Stanley. Stanley closes the car door and BB drives off. Stanley watches BB's car turn the bend, and then he goes toward the office door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley is standing at the filing cabinet going through files. He takes some files and puts them to one side. Then, satisfied that he's got everything he needs, he picks up the files and turns to leave. BB is standing at the door watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know something, Stanley, I can always smell a guy who's not made of tin. He walks over to Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's against the law to steal files. I could call and have you arrested and sent to jail, right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll put everything back, nobody's the wiser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You work for the Commission, is that it? Stan nods "yes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't the Commission have enough information? They got to send out guys like you to spy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we just started out, and if we had some really good hard facts of some infractions, it would give us a lot of credibility in the community. BB walks closer to Stanley, looks at him for a second, grabs him by his tie and pushes him backwards. Stanley crashes into the filing cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what your big problem is, Stanley? You're lazy. If you want to find out stuff, then you dig... you get on the phone... you canvas... 'We're from the Home Improvement Commission...' Go find your leads... that's what we do all the time. You're just lazy, Stanley. If we're doing something wrong, you should collect all your evidence. Instead, you snoop around... steal files. What is this? Undercover time? You think you're breaking up some big drug ring? Is this the Mafia you've infiltrated? All you've got here is a bunch of guys selling tin for Christ sake! (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want some files? He walks over to the filing cabinet, flips through some files and pulls out three files. Stanley has gotten up from the floor. BB throws the files down on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here... here's some jobs I did. Leave Moe out of this... he quit the business. Stanley gathers up the files from the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, get out of here. Stanley starts for the door, and turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's    not gonna be you, it's gonna be    somebody else... and if it's not    tonight, it's gonna be another    time. Stanley exits the office. BB picks up the files that Stanley had taken out of the filing cabinet, and starts to put them back. Then he slams the filing drawers closed very hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB and Nora are in bed together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe if I    talked to him another day he'll    change his mind. I mean, he's    like that... one day, he's this    way and another day he's that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, he's probably, you know, upset about the I.R.S. taking the house and all our stuff. After a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever see a Volkswagen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, those little Volkswagens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a car... a little car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that have to do with anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno... they're interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so interesting about a car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno. It's a little thing... you know, a little thing. Guy tells me they don't even have radiators... they're air-cooled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's interesting... different... something new. I like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wing is standing up at the blackboard chalking out schedules and sales. Tilley stands back and looks at the board, seeing his name up with Mouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Wing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley and Mouse. It looks weird, doesn't it? Looks very weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's hope you have some better luck with Mouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pool hall  is fairly unlit, except for the slight shaft of light  falling over several tables. Gil is play- ing pool with  another tin man. Mouse, Sam, and three or four other tin  men are playing pool.

dialogues.speaker: STAIRS TO POOL HALL
dialogues.text: BB comes down the stairs into the pool hall.

dialogues.speaker: GIL
dialogues.text: He stops playing pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Marengay. He goes over to the office door, opens it and yells to Tilley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Tilley... Mr. Marengay's out here. Tilley comes out of the office and stands looking at BB.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I talk to you in private, or do I have to talk to you over fourteen pool tables? Tilley moves down the hall toward BB.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got enough that's going down between the two of us, but the fact of the matter is that I love your wife, and I want to marry her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care who she marries, but I don't want her marrying you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we just talk about this in a nice, rational manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rational?   You're going to be rational?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got our problems, but let's try and isolate this particular situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isolate... isolate... I like this kind of talk. What the hell nonsense is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you gonna gain from this thing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let me see here... I've got to isolate that for a moment and think it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's going to benefit from making me mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to hear yourself. You know that? You ought to listen to the way you talk. You come in here, you want to take my wife ... you want to isolate this situation... you want to be rational. I've got no tolerance for you, mister. You know what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you're saying is you don't want to discuss this, am I right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like pool? The other tin men move closer to Tilley and BB, crowding in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I enjoy the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we play a little  game of eight ball? If I lose,   I consent to the divorce...  if you lose, you give Nora up...  walk away from her. BB stares at Tilley; Tilley eyes BB.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rack 'em.

dialogues.speaker: CUE BALL
dialogues.text: hitting the balls on the break. A seven ball drops into the pocket. CAMERA PANS TO BB who has a smile on his face at the successful break he just made. He quickly moves around the table, lines up a shot and sinks the ball. Tilley looks a little concerned. BB moves around the table quickly, confidently. He lines up another shot. He carefully strokes the pool cue between his fingers, hits the ball, and sinks the shot. He moves around the table -- he has a particularly complicated shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Combination... side pocket. The tin men react.   BB hits the ball and sinks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's four.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He quickly surveys the     table and sees his next shot. hits the ball, it goes     toward the pocket, but bounces back slightly, missing     the pocket. Tilley quickly goe to work. He sinks his      first shot... his second. He makes a difficult shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir!    Yes, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley    keeps moving around the table, sinking one ball after    the other. He's enthusiastic, excited and confi- dent.     He sinks another ball, and another. He sinks every    ball, then he eyes the eight ball for the coup d grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to shake Tilley) You make this one here, and you win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't I know it... don't I know it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shoots. The eight ball heads for the pocket and doesn't make it. It hangs up on the felt about two feet from the pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB quickly goes to work... sinks every one of his balls. He eyes the eight ball carefully. Tilley's nervous. A couple of the tin men make private side bets whether the ball goes or doesn't. BB lines up the shot; he shoots, and it misses, hanging up on the lip of the pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley quickly moves and sinks the eight ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... that puts an end to one of our differences. Now, concerning you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna beat the crap out of you. You want it here or do you want it outside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside. BB turns his back on Tilley to move toward the door. Tilley swings with all his might and hits BB in the     b of the head. BB almost falls to the ground. Tilley to hit him again. BB hits him in the face, knocking back. Tilley falls back... BB starts to move toward The tin men move in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay out of this... this is between the two of us. BB gets to his feet... the two guys eye one another, moving. BB quickly moves with incredible cat-like speed with four hits into the stomach, really fast, and one hit to Tilley's head. Tilley falls into the rack of pool cues, they all fall to the ground. BB goes to jump on Tilley. He slips on one of the pool cues and falls to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR TO OFFICE
dialogues.text: Wing is standing watching the fight.    He looks disguste ... shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO TILLEY AND BB
dialogues.text: Tilley moves toward BB. BB hits him hard in the stomach again. Tilley keeps coming at BB. He rams him and knocks him to the ground. Tilley pushes BB's head onto the ground, trying to hit it against the floor. BB gets a hand free and hits Tilley hard in the side of the head. The tin men have seen enough and jump in and pull Tilley and BB apart. AD LIBS: "That's enough, you guys" ... "Come on, break it up." BB and Tilley stand up. BB brushes his suit down with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think our business is finished. Tilley just stands watching BB.    BB walks up the steps of the pool hall and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB drives up to the front of the Superior Aluminum Siding building. He stops the car and gets out. He is fairly disheveled and has a bruise on his cheek. He walks up to the entrance of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three or four GIRLS are on the phones canvassing for sales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Improves the insulation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... We'll have a representative in your area... Carly, Cheese and Looney are sitting around a desk drink- ing coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Danny's an example of that. Danny goes into a bar, chicks lined up and down the bar. Walks up to one and says, 'Honey, would you like to fuck?' She'd slap him in the face. He'd move down to the next girl, say the same thing... she'd slap him. Then he'd just keep moving down, going from one girl to the other. Fifteen, maybe sixteen girls would tell him to get lost... to get the hell out of there... BB enters, says "hi" to the Girls, moves to get a coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Call him names... but he doesn't take it personal, you see ... he keeps going, and then the next girl smiles. He says, 'Why don't you buy me a drink'... he scores. Every time. He goes through a lot of girls, takes a lot of slaps in the face, but he never takes it personally... BB moves over to the guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And he always gets what he wants. Looney looks up and sees BB's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Beeb. What happened to you? That broad beat the shit out of you? BB smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you must enjoy these masochistic relationships. Smashes your car... punches you in the face... Bagel walks out of his office and across to NICK, a tin man sitting at a desk across from Looney. He hands Nick a file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bagel)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bagel, you ought to get a load of this broad Beeb's messing with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking over to BB)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks a little too romantic for me. He walks back to his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know who's no longer married to who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we ought to know. There's like a million fucking people living in Baltimore. How many guesses do we get? (NOTE: The following action and dialogue will run concurrently.)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CHEESE                 A MAN comes into the It's not that hard if you      office from outside. think about it.                He's carrying an envelope. He approaches Nick, who is

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: LOONEY BB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHEESE               Want me to find out what You stood up Vivien          they've got against you? Marshall? Are you an         I know a clerk down there. idiot! What an idiot.        For a price I could get the inside scoop. These

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: CARLY BAGEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARLY                Bagel, but I'll be all You're kidding me.           right.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CHEESE                  BB puts the summons into What does this have to do       his breast pocket and with the couple who broke       exits the office. up?

dialogues.speaker: CARLY
dialogues.text: We'll get to that once we've discussed Wilma... they'll still be broken up... we'll get to that in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: LOONEY
dialogues.text: How do you know Wilma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley drives into the parking lot of the Pimlico -- he heads for a dark corner of the lot where about eight cars are parked. As he's about to park his car, he sees Wing talking to Masters in the car next to his. Tilley's a bit confused, stays in his car watching them. After a couple of beats, Wing gets out of the car and heads for the Pimlico. Masters drives off. Tilley gets out of his car and catches up to Wing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Wing, isn't that the putz from the Commission? Points to car driving out of parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masters?   Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell's he doing hanging around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I nailed his ass the other day, Wing. Can't lay a finger on me. I was amazing, you should have been there. I was amazing... I was respectful, courteous, but I was slipping and sliding... they couldn't touch me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a real problem, Tilley. Come inside, I'll buy you a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley and Wing are sitting at a table. The pianist is playing, and people are sitting around the piano joining in with the song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna sell me out to the Commission? Wing, am I hearing this right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm up front with you about this... I'm up front with ya, Tilley. I've got my balls in a vice... what am I gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this about the money I owe you? Are you just pissed? You want to get even because of the horse race? I told ya it was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley, it's got nothing to do with the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're selling me out? You're gonna let them bury me? Jesus Christ, Wing... Jesus Christ! I'm not gonna be able to work in this business? Wing, this was my chosen field!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masters was gonna take this company apart. You're the low man on the totem pole, Tilley. There's a lot of guys earning a good living... no sense for it all to go up in smoke. You understand, don't you, Tilley? It's just business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Tilley, you owe me sixteen plus from the race, and you're in for over two grand on the books, so I tell you what... I'll wipe the slate clean. He takes out his wallet from his pocket, and peels off a few notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's a thou until you get yourself set up. I can do no better than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at the money)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd sell me out for a lousy three thousand dollars? Three thousand dollars and I got to go down the toilet? Jesus Christ, Wing, how long the two of us been busting our asses together ... Jesus Christ! We got some history to this relationship for Christ sake. Masters puts a little squeeze on you, you just sell out. Three thousand dollars?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bottom line is, I'm running a business, Tilley. (he peels off another couple of hundred dollars from his wallet)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's another deuce. I carried you a long time, Tilley. I've done a damn sight more than a lot of other guys would have done for you... and I don't see no gratitude from you. He gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can finish up whenever you like. (throws a few dollars on the table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Tilley. That's the way of the world. He pats Tilley on the back and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley's Cadillac drives into the lot which overlooks the harbor. We see the harbor city lights surrounding the lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RADIO is playing. Tilley stops the car, turns off the lights, but leaves the radio playing. He leans in- to the back of the car and takes a pillow off the back seat. He props the cushion up against the passenger side, and lies down, looking up to the roof of the car.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: of the car sitting in the deserted lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: being fried in a frying pan on a stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill! Better hurry up, everything's ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eggs being slipped onto a plate with some bacon and hash browns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB comes into the kitchen of his apartment.    He is tying his tie. WIDEN SHOT to include Nora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe that you're up so early. This is a rare occasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I just got some business downtown I gotta take care of. He stands there watching Nora as she prepares the plates of food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toast will be ready in a second. Coffee's on the table. He continues to stand watching her -- she's not aware that he's watching her. She waits for the toast to pop up out of the toaster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Nora. I... um... I... er ... lied to you the other day. Nora is still waiting for the toast, looking inside the toaster to see if it's getting brown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to see Tilley about the divorce. She turns to look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was not too agreeable, and one thing led to another, and we decided to shoot some pool to settle the matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The toast pops up -- she ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We played pool. If I won he'd give you up, if I lost I'd give you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You played pool for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora, I had no choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the most despicable thing I've ever heard in my life. I mean, it's disgusting... guys shooting pool to determine my future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora, I had no choice! (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hand me the toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the toast yourself. BB takes the toast out of the toaster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just trying to be honest. It's been on my mind... on my conscience. He picks up a plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This plate yours or mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you take both... maybe you can choke to death on one of them. BB takes one of the plates and goes toward the table. Nora watches him a beat, amazed that he doesn't seem to recognize the seriousness of the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you be so... how     can you not understand how wrong     that is? I can't understand that     mentality! Shoot pool for me! It's      insane. BB dips his toast into his eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley is not the     most rational man in this world.      I tried to talk to him... he     wouldn't listen. So, what      are my options? You know what I'm     saying? What are my options?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you had to shoot pool! Don't you understand that ... don't you understand how crazy that is? You're sitting there... you're eating your eggs as if it's normal business in life here! Like feudal lords or something you used to read about in history books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'm sorry. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lost. He dips more toast into his eggs and eats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I blew the eight ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means I'm supposed to give you up, and I'm never supposed to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you stop eating the eggs for a minute! How can you tell me things like this and casually eat your eggs?! What does this mean, Bill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm supposed to give you up as part of honoring that agreement, but I'm not that honorable a guy. He smiles, takes a quick sip of his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you running off so fast here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, I got some business downtown. He gives her a kiss. Starts to go, turns back, gives her another kiss, more passionate this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you later. He goes down the hall to walk out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora walks behind him, stands and watches him go out the door and down the front steps. He gets into his car and drives off. Nora stands at the door watching the car drive away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley pulls his Cadillac into a parking space just a little up the street from the tobacco warehouse which houses the Home Improvement Commission. He gets out of his car, locks the door and starts down the street. BB's car drives past Tilley. CAMERA FOLLOWS BB's car as he pulls into a parking space close to the Commission building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corridor off the main hearing room. The hearing is not yet in session. Tilley sits on a bench against a wall. He glances up, his eyes drop and then he looks ACROSS CAMERA. CAMERA PANS TO the opposite side of the corri- dor where BB sits on another bench against a wall. BB glances off at Tilley and then drops his eyes. CAMERA PANS BACK TO Tilley. A few beats go by. Both men are uncomfortable with one another's presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally, to BB)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta testify, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah. I already testified once. I beat 'em before, I'll beat 'em again. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a high-priced mouthpiece to speak for ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need one.    I don't expect to win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave them some pretty incriminating evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gave them evidence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only way I could think to get out of this business. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points, laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, that's good... that's good, yeah. There's activity in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hearing for the Home Improvement Commission is now in session. Tilley stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to BB)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... how's Nora?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's doin' all right. A MAN comes out of the hearing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernest Tilley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... here. (turns to BB)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take good care of her.

dialogues.speaker: HEARING ROOM
dialogues.text: of the Home Improvement Commission. Five  or six commissioners are behind a long table, led by John Masters, there is a gallery of observers, and Tilley sits at the defense table across from the commissioners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into microphone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you aware that that's a violation of sections 258 and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not aware of the section numbers. Sometimes you get a little overzealous in the heat of the sales pitch, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB is watching the proceedings.      CAMERA HOLDS ON him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it the heat of the sales pitch on February 23rd of this year that made you write across a contract 'This Job Is Free'?

dialogues.speaker: ON TILLEY
dialogues.text: who is falling apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I remember, no sale was made concerning those customers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It fell out because a loan couldn't be arranged, but the people did agree in principle. (beat) The point that we'd like to stress, is that you misled these people. Told them the job was free. Then you sent in your closer with some cover story about how you had suffered a nervous breakdown, and a sale was ultimately made for twenty-three hundred and seventy- seven dollars. That is misleading and deceptive sales practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was    temporary insanity. I don't    know... it just came over me ... it    might have been something I ate.     I don't know... it was crazy,    I'm the first to admit it was a    crazy thing to do. Believe me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting him off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have other specific examples of deceptive sales practices on your behalf concerning a job carried out on December 11, 1962. You violated sections 241 and 247. And concerning a job sold to Mr. and Mrs. DeFranco on October 9, 1962, violations of sections 251 and 257 took place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are all these numbers here? I'm not familiar with all these section violations.

dialogues.speaker: ON BB
dialogues.text: who is watching the proceedings intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the feeling of this commission that these infractions are severe violations of the Home Improvement Laws, and therefore constitute misuse of the license to sell aluminum siding as approved by this state.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the decision of this commission to revoke your license to sell aluminum siding...

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA ON TILLEY
dialogues.text: He's not very happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Which will prohibit you from practicing in the state of Maryland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure? Maybe the guys want to think this over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Tilley. You may hand over your license to the clerk of the commission on your way out.

dialogues.speaker: TILLEY
dialogues.text: gets up from the table and goes to the back of the room to exit the building. He stops at a desk just inside the door where the clerk is sitting. Tilley pulls out his wallet, takes out a small document, and throws it down on the desk. He exits the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same as before, except now we see Stanley enter and sit amongst the observers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will Mr. William Babowski please come forward. BB walks over to the defense table and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the right to have a lawyer present if you so wish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not wish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilley walks down the street toward his car. Suddenly he realizes that there's an empty space and his car is gone. Tilley's a little confused, thinking that perhaps he parked elsewhere. A YOUNG BLACK KID walks up to Tilley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you have a car parked here? A Cadillac?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   What about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man told me to say they took it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who took it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man said, the tax man.     Gave me a dollar to tell you so. Tilley walks over and stands in the empty space where his car had been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tax man! Fucking I.R.S. How low can you get? How low can you get? He walks around in the space as if somehow his car might reappear. He mumbles to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're lowlife. How can people come and take a man's car?... His Cadillac?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hearing is continuing with BB at the defense table, and Stanley watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think with the number of violations on your record, Mr. Babowski, this commission has no recourse but to revoke your state license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you please drop    off your license with the clerk    of the commission on your way    out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning into the microphone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. BB gets up and walks to the back of the  room. He stops at the same desk as Tilley, but instead  of going into his wallet like Tilley, he just reaches  into his suit pocket, pulls out a license document and  tosses it onto the table. Then he heads out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB walks down the street, making for his car. He sees Tilley still standing in the vacant parking space. Tilley sees BB. BB stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about your license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   You in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   They got my license as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing standing there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where my car used to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stolen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I.R.S. Fucking bandits! Bandits! Thieving sons of bitches! BB looks at Tilley for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need a ride uptown?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could use one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. They cross the street and go toward BB's Cadillac. BB gets in the driver's side, Tilley gets in the passenger side, and the car pulls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB's driving and Tilley's in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some bullshit commission, huh? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, where's it written it the Constitution that says you can't hustle for money? Where's it written? It ain't like I went into an alley and hit a guy over the head with a brick and stole his money... not like I broke into somebody's house and stole his stuff. All I'm doing is selling... where's the crime in that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what the world's coming to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're telling me. I don't know what the world's coming to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BB's still driving and Tilley's in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what our big crime is? We're nickel and dime guys. We're small time hustlers.  They got us because we're hustling nickels and dimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nickels and dimes. You got a good point there, BB. You're right on the money with that kind of thinking. BB stops the car at a stop sign. Something catches BB's eye. THROUGH the windshield we see a Volkswagen "beetle" going from right to left.

dialogues.speaker: BB
dialogues.text: as he watches the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta find a new business to get into.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New? Very hard to find something new to get into. BB puts his foot on the gas and starts to drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe... maybe not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better put on my thinking cap... not easy to think of something new.

dialogues.speaker: CITY
dialogues.text: showing stacks of houses as the Cadillac drives away. A MacDonald golden arch is being put in place by a crane on the horizon line. It's almost as if it's a rainbow across the far side of town, and the Cadillac will drive through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, we'll find something. It's just a matter of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... matter of time. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I hear the new Cadillac's gonna be out in a couple of months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... they're changing the body. I hear it's a beaut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I should put in my order now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you talking about? You ain't got a pot to piss in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the pot... I'll fill it.
